Sir,

I have the honour to forward to the Dept. Account rendered by T. J. Wallace for repairs he did at French Bay property.

Amount of account $25.15.

I would recommend that the account be paid as the work was done by Mr. Wallace and the charges are reasonable, as I do not think that Mr. Wallace would ask for anything that he was not entitled to.

I have the honour to be, sir,

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Secretary, Dept.,
Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa June 7th 1923.

Sir,-

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with which you submitted a voucher amounting to $25.15 in favour of Mr T.J. Wallace, for repairs made to the French Bay property therein referred to; and in reply I return the account herewith in order that it may be rendered so as to show details of the charges of $20.15 and $5.00. Receipted accounts for material purchased should be attached to the voucher when it is submitted again for payment.

I have to remind you in this connection that all accounts must be rendered in detail before they can be passed for payment. This is necessary in order that the requirements of the Auditor General's Office may be met.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

T.W. Stout Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill, Ont.
Sir,

I have the honour to inform the Dept. that I interviewed Mr. Wallace regarding receipts for material and also labour in connection with the improvements which he made at French Bay School property, and he informs me that he forwarded any receipts that he had to the Dept. when he first sent in his account and it will be impossible for him to get any more as the parties from whom he purchased part of the material are away form here now.

I have the honour to be, sir,

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

August 25th, 1923.

Sir,-

I am in receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant, with which you forwarded to the Department an account of $4.65 from the Toronto Globe for printing notices advertising for a teacher for the Indian School and in reply I have to inform you that payment of the account cannot be made until the Department receives a clipping of the advertisement charged for therein.

It is necessary for this Department to send the said account, together with a sample of the work done, to the King's Printer for taxation previous to payment being considered.

The voucher is returned herewith and you should attach the clipping thereto and return it without delay.

Your obedient servant,

(A.F. MacKenzie),
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

T.A. Stout, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill, Ont.

EXTRACT FROM JUNE QUARTER RETURN OF THE SAUGEEN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

-----------------

The roof on one of the clock rooms is leaking badly.

The interior of the school room also needs some attention. The walls are in need of whitening and the woodwork should have a coat of varnish.

The toilet requires whitewashing and window glass.

The boys' toilet must have a new water trough.

Malcolm McIvor,
Teacher,
Ottawa, July 28th, 1925.

Sir:

The teacher of the Saugeen Village Indian Day School, in his report for the June quarter, last, states that the roof over one of the cloak rooms is leaking badly. He also states that the interior walls of the classroom are in need of whitening, and that the woodwork should be washed and given a coat of varnish. He further states that the toilet requires to be whitewashed and that some window glass should be supplied, also that the drain in the boys' toilet is in need of a new water trough.

I have to request that you will report as soon as possible on the recommendations made by the teacher, and state what repairs, if any, you would recommend be carried out. The approximate cost of any work which you recommend be done should be stated. Please reply as soon as possible in order that if it is decided to have any of this work undertaken it can be completed during the present summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Saul Putnam, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill,
Ont.
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your favour of the 28th inst., no 31-2-5, re repairs to Village school.

In reply I beg to say that I would recommend this work. The woodwork will require two coats of varnish and the window sashes a coat of white paint. The roof of one of the cloak rooms needs shingling and the ceiling of this room will have to be re-plastered as the leak in the roof has destroyed the plaster. The walls all require whitening. One of the storm windows should have three panes of glass. The toilets need whitewashing and two panes of glass. The boys' toilet should have a new water trough and the doors need new latches.

I have made a careful estimate of the cost of this work, and would say that it would cost from one hundred and fifty to one hundred and sixty dollars, and would recommend that it be done as soon as possible.

It would appear that there has been a lot of money spent since I took this office, but apparently these buildings have been neglected and the work that I have recommended is absolutely necessary.

I have the honor to be Sir,

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 5th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, in which you recommend that certain repairs and painting be carried out to the Saugeen Village Indian Day School, and giving an estimate of the cost of same.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have the woodwork given two coats of varnish, and the window sashes and trimming a coat of white paint. The roof of the cloak room should be reshingled, and the ceiling of this room replastered and the walls whitened. You may also arrange to have three panes of glass put in the storm windows. The toilets should also be whitewashed, and 2 panes of glass installed. A new water trough should also be installed in the boys' toilet, and latches placed on the doors.

If possible, you should arrange to have all of the above work done by day labour, you to arrange for the purchase and delivery of the materials required. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for the labour employed. These you should certify and send to the Department for payment, together with vouchers, properly certified, covering the cost of the paint, shingles and other materials. We note that you estimate the cost of all the above work to be approximately $160.00. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to have the work completed in the most satisfactory manner and at the lowest possible cost.

The above work should receive your early attention, and, if possible, should be completed before the school reopens after the present summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
A. F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Relative to resolution No. 2 of the regular council meeting of the Saugeen Band held on the 6th instant, approving of an expenditure from Band funds to the amount of $500 to install a new furnace in the Saugeen Village Indian Day School, I beg to say that the Department will approve of this expenditure for the purpose. You may make the necessary arrangements to have this new furnace installed during the coming summer holidays. You should obtain prices for the supplying of either a McClary or Gurney furnace, and arrange to have the one which you consider would be the most satisfactory and could be installed at the lowest price obtained. Sir,

Mr. Inspector Parker, who recently visited the Saugeen Reserve, states that the Saugeen Village School has no well and that the water supply is now being taken from the river not far from where the closets are situated. Sir,

I have the honor to reply to your letter No. 31-2-5, dated June 1st, with reference to a well for the Saugeen Village school.

I beg to say, a pump would cost around $12.00 and the piping 22¢ per ft. As good water is usually got between 15 and 20 ft. I would recommend that a point be driven down as it would be much cheaper than either drilling or digging; these points cost around $4.00.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,

Ottawa, November 4, 1930.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my visit of inspection to the Saugeen Agency.

SAUGEEN VILLAGE SCHOOL:

The teacher, Mr. Knetchel, impressed me as very capable and interested in the work. There is a live, healthy atmosphere in the classroom. The pupils are interested in their studies. One has only to see their deportment in the classroom to be assured that good progress is being made.

This school needs some repairs and the following are recommended:

In the basement a door is required between the furnace room and the steps leading to the rear basement entrance. The lack of a door makes the classroom very cold. The building should be painted inside and out next summer. It is showing signs of wear. It will need two coats of paint.

The teacher would like to have a map of North America.

Thos. McGookin.
Inspector.
Ottawa, November 17, 1930.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Saugeen Village Indian Day School, recommends that, in the basement, a door be installed between the furnace room and the steps leading to the rear basement entrance. He states that the lack of the door makes the classroom very cold.

I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange to have a door installed. A lock with key should also be supplied, if same is considered by you to be necessary. You should see that this door is installed in a satisfactory manner, that no expense is incurred, and that the work is completed before the extreme cold weather sets in. After the work has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

The Inspector also recommends that this building be painted, both inside and outside, next summer, as it is showing signs of wear. He states it will require two coats of paint. I have to request that you will draw this matter to the attention of the Department early next spring, giving full particulars as to the amount of paint required and the approximate cost of the material and labour. If the out buildings require painting, you should also include them in your estimate.

The Inspector speaks highly of the work being performed by the teacher at this school, and states that the pupils are interested in their studies.

An order is being placed with the Government Stationery Office here to forward to the teacher a map of North America.

Your obedient servant,

D. Robertson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill,
Ont.

Saugeen Village School.

Ottawa, June 5, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his recent inspection of the Saugeen Village Indian Day School, states that the following repairs are required:

Ceiling in both clothes closets should be repaired.

Eavestroughing on the entrance porch is disconnected and should be repaired as soon as possible.

Pump is out of order - pipe needs to be lengthened 6' or 8'.

You should arrange to have the above repairs carried out during the coming summer holidays, keeping all expenses for the purpose as low as possible. When the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Inspector states that the playground is very uneven. He recommends that it be plowed up, levelled and seeded down. I shall be pleased to have a report from you as to the work you would recommend be carried out in the levelling of these grounds, and the approximate cost of same.

I may say that we will have no funds this summer for the painting of the school building, both inside and outside.

Your obedient servant,

D. Robertson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill,
Ont.

J. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
Sir:-

I have the honor to refer to Department letter no. 31-2-5, dated June 8th, 1931, with reference to repairs required to the Saugeen Village Indian Day School.

I beg to say, the playground in connection with this school is divided, part being for the girls and part for the boys, it is very uneven and should be plowed and seeded down. The soil is very light and sandy, if it was plowed it may require a coat of heavier loam to keep it from blowing away, I would recommend that one side be plowed at a time, if the girls side were plowed this summer it would be ready for use next year when the other side could be plowed, It would cost around $25.00 to have the one side plowed, leveled, top dressed and seeded down.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT from Inspector McGookin's Report dated May 10th, 1932, on his inspection of the Saugeen Agency on the 29th and 30th ultimo.

Saugeen Village School:

Mr. W. M. Knetchel, teacher, 18 on roll, 15 present. Average for April, 15. Classroom clean and tidy. Discipline good. Pupils look healthy and tidy. No complaints were made to me regarding the teacher's work on this visit. The school property generally is in good condition.

The interior should be redecorated when funds are available.

The furnace room floor - 108 sq. feet, should be cemented.

The south side of roof will soon need reshingling. It will be alright for another year.

Part of the ridge board is off. This should be replaced at once to avoid damage to the roof.

Half a dozen wall pictures for classroom would add interest and appearance to it.
Ottawa, May 26, 1932.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his recent inspection of the Saugeen Village Indian Day School, recommends that the interior of the building be redecorated, also that the floor of the furnace room be cemented and that the part of the ridge board which is off be replaced, in order to avoid damage to the roof.

I have to request that you will arrange to have the repairs required made to the ridge board at an early date. When this work is completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Regarding the redecorating of the interior of the school and cementing of the floor of the furnace room, I would request that you state whether you consider this work to be urgent, or if it could remain over for another year. If you consider that any of this work should be carried out at the present time, I would request that you forward full particulars of the work you would recommend be performed and the approximate cost of any materials and labour required.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

EXTRACT from Report of Inspector J.M. Game, regarding his visit to the SAUGEEN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on May 10th, 1932.

Original on File 31-2-6.

The school building is a substantial brick building in a good state of repair except for a few rather important features. The walls and ceiling of the classroom require redecorating badly and the plaster in two places is loose. Parts of the roof require reshingling.

The water closets should have boxes provided so that cleaning might be effected more readily.

The furnace was so crudely installed that it is impossible to keep the basement near it neat. More cement work is required around it.
Sir,

I have the honor to refer to Department letter No. 31-2-5, dated May 26th, regarding repairs required to the Saugeen Village Indian Day School.

I beg to say, as there is no floor in part of the furnace room it makes it hard to keep it clean, a cement floor would cost about $11.00, which I would recommend being done.

Regarding the redecorating of the interior of the building, this work should be done but before it is carried out the south side of the roof should be reshingled; the shingles on this side have rotted and during recent high winds a number of them have blown away leaving the sheeting bare. It would cost around $85.00 to reshingle this side of the roof. I would recommend that the roof be reshingled during the coming holidays and the redecorating left over for another year.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,

The top of the fire box in the furnace has burned through with the result that smoke comes up into the classroom through a hot air register - in fact flames can be seen through the register from above. The smoke is hard on the lungs of the pupils and teacher. The decorating of the walls and ceiling have suffered from this, also. Walls and ceiling alike require re-decorating very badly. The plaster is off part of the ceiling and part of one wall. Through the broken plaster in the ceiling, daylight may be observed in several places between the chimney and the flashing, which is supposed to be rain proof. A year ago the south side of the school was reshingled but the north half and the part over the entrance were left for a later occasion. The north side should be done now as there are leaks in several places.

A number of new translucent window shades are required, some window panes require reglazing and some replacing. The well is dry.

The caretaking might be improved in several respects. Dust and papers are being swept down the cold air vent. The upper parts of the windows (both inside and storm) have not been cleaned in two years. Consequently, they are filthy. The desks are not well dusted.
Ottawa, November 23, 1933.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Saugeen Village Indian Day School, states as follows:

"The top of the fire-box in the furnace has burned through, with the result that smoke comes up into the classroom through a hot air register - in fact, flames can be seen through the register from above. The smoke is hard on the lungs of the pupils and teacher. The decorating of the walls and ceiling have suffered from this, also. Walls and ceiling alike require re-decorating very badly. The plaster is off part of the ceiling and part of one wall. Through the broken plaster in the ceiling, daylight may be observed in several places between the chimney and the flashing, which is supposed to be rain proof. A year ago the south side of the school was reshingled, but the north half and the part over the entrance were left for a later occasion. The north side should be done now as there are leaks in several places.

"A number of new translucent window shades are required, some window panes require reglazing and some replacing. The well is dry.

"The caretaking might be improved in several respects. Dust and papers are being swept down the cold air vent. The upper parts of the windows (both inside and storm) have not been cleaned in two years. Consequently, they are filthy. The desks are not well dusted."

The Department considers that you should have reported the condition of the furnace. You should state,

- as soon

D. Robertson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill, Ont.
as soon as possible, the cost of carrying out the repairs required to place this furnace in a satisfactory condition. You should also state the amount involved in having the plaster on the ceiling and walls repaired and the repairs necessary to make the north side of the roof and the part over the entrance water-tight during the present winter. Further, please advise the Department how many window shades are required and the cost. You should arrange to have any window panes requiring same re-glazed and any broken windows replaced.

You will note the Inspector's remarks regarding the caretaking. Please inform the caretaker that dust and papers are not to be swept down the cold air vents. Also, please instruct him that the windows, both inside and outside, as well as the storm windows, should be thoroughly cleaned and also that the furnishings are to be well dusted from time to time.

The Department would like to receive, as soon as possible, your report concerning the cost of effecting the repairs as mentioned above.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Saugeen Village school.

Recommendations:

Ottawa, April 12, 1946.

Mr. D. Robertson, Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill, Ontario.

The following recommendations have been received from Inspector Game with reference to the Saugan Village Indian Day School:

1. Conductor pipes from the eaves. There are none. This condition has been reported annually for years.

2. Clean thoroughly all windows - storm and permanent sash. The windows in this school have never been observed by the writer in a clean condition. The classroom, etc., otherwise is in a clean condition.

3. The plaster on the ceiling has become discoloured - apparently from a smoking furnace - decorating is recommended.

4. Place shades on ALL the south windows. There are none.

5. Put two north classroom doors on their hinges. Neither will close properly and this makes the classroom unnecessarily draughty in the cold weather.

6. The pump is again in need of attention.

Items 2, 4, 5 and 6 should receive attention during the Easter holidays.

Dear Mrs. Logan:

There is a vacant lot opposite the school, which belongs to the band and a splendid location for the residence. The residence would be about forty yards from the school, and there would be a good garden in connection with it.

Please let me hear from you in reference to this at your earliest convenience.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the erection of a residence for the teacher of the Saugeen Village Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say that it is the intention to erect the building during the coming summer.

Regarding the vacant lot opposite the school on which you recommend that the residence be built, I have to request that you will state whether it will be necessary to pay compensation to an individual Indian for any improvements thereon, or whether the lot is owned by the Band in common. If it is owned by the latter, it is presumed that the Indians will set aside the plot of land required without any charge therefor. Please inform the Department fully regarding this matter, in order that the question of the site may be settled and the land acquired before building operations commence.

Sir:

It is thought that this building could be erected by day labour, under the supervision of a competent foreman, you to purchase, after securing competitive prices, the lumber and other material required. If you can undertake this work, I shall be pleased if you will furnish a sketch showing the dimensions and the general lay-out of the building which you would recommend be erected. Sir,

I have the honor to refer to your letter #31-2-8 of April 9th, and beg to state that the lot referred to in your letter is owned by the band in common, and compensation would have to be paid to E. Joshua for fence built, but would be very little. I am enclosing plan of the village, proposed site carefully marked. Site would be four rods by ten rods, and fifty yards from the school building.

In further reference to your letter of April 11th, in reference to the building of a residence for our teacher, I have had considerable experience in the building line, and am quite willing to undertake the work of looking after the erection of the house. I can hire a competent foreman and other necessary labor to do the work.

I am enclosing you an estimate of the material required, also the cost of same delivered. In making payment for this material, I can arrange with some of the local millmen to take logs delivered on the shore at the following prices:

$22.00 per M for Hemlock.
$30.00 per M for Pine.
40¢ each for round ties.

As this timber is quite close to the shore, and the Indians are doing very little, it would give them some employment, and thereby save on the amount of capital funds required for the payment of material.

As you are aware this work will take considerable of my time, as I will have to be on the job, and it will be necessary to employ some office help, and I think I should be allowed some remuneration, at least to the extent I would have to pay for office help.

I am enclosing you a sketch of the house I have made an estimate on 27x28 ft. 16 ft. studding, with cottage roof, and 8 ft. verandah in front. House to be double sided, papered, lathed and plastered. Am also enclosing a diagram of the lot proposed to build on.

I have the honor to remain,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

P.S. The Indians are averse to letting this by tender, they want the work.

Dept. Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, December 4, 1934.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, enclosing labour returns for payments made by you in connection with the erection of the teacher's residence on the Saugeen Reserve. The total of these returns shows an outlay by you of $1,262.33. I would call your attention to the return for the week ending August 16th, which you totalled at $68.00 when the correct amount is $79.00.

It is noted that from the week of June 14th to that of August 30th, you have paid out $62.00 to Edith Longe, presumably for office work, and exception must be taken to this payment as the same was not authorized by this Department and does not necessarily come under the class of which might be called labour in connection with the teacher's residence. These payments to Miss Longe must be disallowed unless good reason can be shown why payment should be made and in any event her services should not have been retained by you without obtaining the permission of the Department.

It is noted that some weeks George Nickel, mason, was paid seventy-five cents an hour and sometimes eighty-five cents an hour; an explanation is required why the difference in rate of payment.

You were advanced to pay for the erection of this residence $1,552.33, made up as follows:

Saul Putnam, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill, Ont.
2.

Cheque No. 1163 for .................. $ 500.00
Cheque No. 2747 for .................. 800.00
Cheque No. 3654 for .................. 141.93
Cheque No. 5242 for .................. 110.40

Of these advances made to you, you have paid $1,262.33 for labour and $300.00 to Mr. Diebel for lumber or a total of $1,562.33, but as you have paid Miss Longe $62.00 without the authority of the Department, there is to be refunded by you the sum of $62.00.

This residence which was estimated to cost $2,500.00 has cost to date $3,205.17, less $62.00 to be refunded by you as pointed out above, or $1,353.17 more than the estimate, so that the Department would like an explanation from you why the cost has been so excessive.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter 31-2-8 of the 4th inst.

With regard to the first paragraph of your letter, would you kindly send me a copy of the time sheet for week ending August 16th, as I sent both copies.

Regarding paragraph 2, in your letter 31-2-8 of May 13th, you authorized me to have office help. While this work was going on at the teacher's residence and French Bay culverts I was working fifteen and sixteen hours a day all through holiday time. I worked ten hours a day at these two places the same as the other men. The foreman, Mr. Aitchison wanted to quit three times, as the Indians are very hard to get along with. It was absolutely necessary for me to have office help.

Regarding George Nickel, the first time I employed him was at $5 an hour for plastering. I started with Indians, who told me they could plaster, but found they could not without a practical man to lead them. Nickel wanted $1.00 an hour as that is the regular price paid plasterers, but agreed to come for $5. I was acting foreman at the time the plastering was going on. The foreman I had, Mr. John Aitchison was an all round man, but not a mason. I let him go while the plastering and putty coating was going on, for I could foreman that part of the work as well as he could. The reason I got Nickel for 75¢ per hour was he said he would come for the putty coating for 75¢ an hour if I would get a white man to work with him, as he did not like working with Indians. I knew of another man Bruce McKay, of Fort Algin, and employed him at 75¢ an hour. My reason for having the two plastering, I had to have a tender for them, and it would cost the same for the two as for one.

Regarding teacher's residence costing $3905.17, there sure is some mistake, as we have roughly $200.00 for extras to pay yet. It seems impossible to get these people to send in their accounts. I had to put up a she to keep the lime and tools in, as there was nothing on the lot, and if things were not kept locked up they would be taken away. I dug a well and put in a cheap crib to hold the sand back, as I wanted to test this well and it held out O.K. I also had to put up a closet, which took lumber, and I have about five hundred feet left. Would you kindly send a copy of accounts paid, as I feel sure there must be a mistake. When I send in an account you send the cheque direct to the person, and I do not know if the account is paid or not, as I receive no word of this cheque being sent.
Sir —

I have had a good many responsible positions, and never was accused of keeping any person's money, and I do not think at my time of life, it would be worth while.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir—

I have the honor to refer to your letter 31-2-8 of the 13th inst. re building a stable for the teacher of the Saugeen day school.

I do not think it is necessary to have a stable on the teacher's residence. This matter has been brought up in the Council, and it was left to be considered at the next meeting.

Mr. McIvor has nothing of any kind to put in a stable except a second hand Ford car, which I think belongs to an insurance company, nor is he in a position to buy anything. As for transportation, there is a bus passes his door twice a day running between Owen Sound and Southampton, and the jitneys run out here for the fee of ten cents, and I think for Mr. McIvor's own interests he is better without anything. There are buildings of this kind at Scotch Settlement and French Bay that are going to wreck more than if they were used, and if Mr. McIvor wants a building of this kind I would recommend him to transfer to French Bay.

Sir,-

Ottawa 23rd February 1900-

Sir-

In reply to your letter of the 3rd Instant, reporting on the charges made against John Burr, School Teacher, at Scotch Settlement, I beg to direct your attention to Section 134 of the Indian Act, as amended by 53 Vic., Cap 28, Sec 10 and 57-58 Vic. Cap 32, Sec 10, which provides that no school teacher on an Indian Reserve shall trade with any Indian, or sell to him directly or indirectly any goods or supplies, cattle or other animals, without the special license, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, which license he may at any time revoke.

As Mr. Burr has admitted that he buys timber and acts as Agent for Mr. Assmus, of Allenford, and as the Indians are dissatisfied with his doings in this capacity, I have to request you to inform him that the letter authorizing him to measure wood during holidays and at times when not occupied with school duties did not give him permission to buy or traffic in wood, and as the permission to measure has been either misunderstood or abused, the Department has revoked it, and in future he must comply strictly with the Act as cited and cease to interfere in timber matters, unless specially authorized by you in writing to do any measurements which the Indians of the Band may require.

John Scoffield, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill,
Ont.

Your obedient servant

OTTAWA, 22nd May, 1900

The Secretary:

Mr. Agent Scoffield forwards a petition signed by a number of Indians residing in the Scotch Settlement school district, asking for the dismissal of Mr. John Burr, the teacher of their school.

Charges were made against Mr. Burr in February last of his trafficking in timber and irregularity in conducting the school, and Mr. Inspector Macrae, who had an investigation made by Agent Scoffield, states that in looking over the evidence he is inclined to think that the complaints as to irregularity in opening school and leaving during school hours should be dismissed. The other charge of dealing in timber was merely admitted and it was ordered to be stopped. It was not at the time thought necessary to dismiss Burr from his position as teacher and the Indians have laid no additional charge against him, but simply state that they wish to have a change like the other two schools on the reserve. This seems to be hardly sufficient grounds to ask for his dismissal, but as the Agent requests to be informed as to what answer to make to the petitioners I should like to be advised.

Gentlemen,

Permit me respectfully to inform you that I was very much disappointed when I was informed by Mr. J. Wallace, teacher at French Bay, that the Department of Indian Affairs refused to give the teachers on the Saugeen Reserve an increase in their salaries.

I understand that the minimum salary for male teachers is Four Hundred Dollars per annum, and nearly all the teachers in the white schools have got an increase in their salaries this year. I have been offered $50.00 per year to go to Manitoba and if I cannot get an increase I will be compelled to tender the Department of Indian Affairs my resignation. I have been teaching on the Saugeen Reserve for nearly Twenty-two Years during that time I have supported ten of a family but in order to do it I was compelled to work out in holidays.
I think that I should receive enough salary for teaching to support my family without manual labor on the farm during holidays. The legislature of Ontario has passed an Act to increase teachers' salaries and I think that the teachers in Indian schools should receive the benefit of the law as well as others.

In conclusion, I hope that the Honorable Gentlemen of the Department of Indian Affairs will see their way clearly to grant the teachers an increase in their salaries.

I am

Gentlemen,

Your obedient servant,

John Burt,
Teacher
Scotch Settlement,
Sangues Reserve.
Ottawa, January 31, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. John Burr, teacher of the Scotch Settlement school has written the Department applying for an increase of salary. He is at present in receipt of $350 per year and has taught this school for the past twenty-two years.

We have written Mr. Wallace, teacher of the French Bay school, on the same reserve, advising him that his salary had been increased to $400, and if length of service and efficiency count, Mr. Burr is equally entitled to an increase.

Mr. Public School Inspector McCool in his general remarks on Mr. Burr's school says: "Mr. Burr is very active and enthusiastic in his work and seems to understand child nature, especially the Indian children, very well. The schools at French Bay and the Scotch Settlement are models of neatness, cleanliness and good order and would put to shame many of the public schools throughout the county. Both Mr. Burr and Mr. Wallace seem to be the right men in the right place."

In view of the Inspector's report it would seem to be a pity to lose Mr. Burr's services for the sake of $50. He says he will be forced to resign unless he can obtain more salary. He has a large family to support and has devoted the best portion of his life to teaching the Indians on this reserve, who pay the salaries and are well able to stand the increase.

I advertised last May for a teacher for the Scotch Settlement school and received a number of applications. The applications received in May were from women. I had advertisements put into the papers again recently, but so far no applications have been received. As I am not familiar with the conditions at Scotch Settlement I am taking the liberty of writing to the Indian Agent, Mr. John Scoffield, to secure his advice as to whether a married teacher is necessary or whether a lady teacher could be suitably accommodated. I am also requesting him to let me have the names of the teachers from whom he has had applications.

As I have been appointed General Secretary of the Missionary Society in succession to Dr. Sutherland, it is my intention to get into personal touch with all our Indian Missions and schools as soon as circumstances will permit. Any assistance which the Department can give me at this time in the securing of a suitable teacher for Scotch Settlement school will be appreciated.

I have just received a letter which was forwarded to the Secretary of Home Missions and handed to me by him, in which an application is made for appointment to the Scotch Settlement school by Mrs. M. McDonald, Southampton, who holds a third-class District certificate, and has taught school on the Manitoulin Island for over ten years, and for a short time was teacher in one of the mission schools on that island. She asks for a salary of $450. I understand, however, that the Department requires that teachers shall hold a second-class certificate. I shall be glad to be informed on this point.

Yours respectfully,

J. E. Egerton Shore
General Secretary.

Sir,

I feel it is becoming to close & according to request I submit my report. We are progressing a little. We have rather better attendance obtained however by an almost constant fight. That is the only word that will express the state of affairs exactly. My Tenant Officer dislikes going the rounds so often & I cannot see the use of allowing a child to remain out a week or two before sending after it. So we differ. I believe he intends to have the situation discussed at the approaching Council. Whatever that may mean I know not. I am determined to do my duty faithfully while I remain here. Council or no Council I expect the pupils to stand by me just as faithfully. We have no late pupils now. I think dingy in the morning has encouraged them to make an effort to be on time. Yesterday or rather on Saturday I ordered from Mr. Cameron a little over $5 supplies for domestic material. You will receive bill shortly. I hope to make that an incentive to diligence & more regular attendance & have informed pupils that any made up material will be given to a pupil requiring the services of Tenant Officer to enforce attendance. I took the liberty of procuring some goods.
to be made into pocket-handkerchiefs so that in an article they all require a more porous. I shall be obliged to give each pupil one so that there can be no excuse for uncleanness. Inspector McCool visited us last week. You will hear from him. We need say nothing on that subject. We badly need modern seats. I have not room for all as they are at present. How I wish we had a building like the one at Saugus. There is room there to accommodate every pupil in the reserve, basement etc., all up to date. I believe a consolidated school would be a good thing. Then Manual Training, Domestic Science & English education could be successfully carried on & boys & girls would be benefitted alike. I have been teaching hygiene every day since I came but do not have any time set apart for that specially. It would only be wasted time here as they do not understand the language well enough to benefit by it. I insist on clean hands, nails, faces, heads &c & talk to them about keeping feet dry &c &c but I have to illustrate to make them understand my meaning. Average this month is 18 so far I have 31 names on roll. So there are a good many to stir up still. Yours faithfully,

Mrs. B. Robb

Sir,

It is scarcely time for another report but I am daily having my eyes opened wider & wider & must relieve the pressure by pacing on the campus. Monday March 6 only my school called to order—showing having no less than 31 pupils in it. My average for that week was 27+ and I had 28 yesterday & 27 today. I am extremely annoyed by the irregularity of one family & something must be done to correct it as the truant officer seems powerless—all my threats have no effect on them & certainly tend to lessen any influence over the others. The father's name is Fred Walgeezee. He has 3 children—2 boys & 1 girl aged respectively 14, 12 & 8 all in the first form. The boys are only a shade better than wild animals & spend most of their time racing over the reserve behind two great dogs which they have trained to draw them about. I think a hint that it may be necessary to remove them to some institution where they would be under proper control might be beneficial.

To return to that Monday I had some new comers, one 12 years old—a great strong girl who had scarcely ever been inside the school & I know there are others in the same predicament for on my walks I see children who have not been inside the school since I came here. There is surely something wrong when careless parents are allowed to neglect their children so shamefully in this Christian country.

Another month has rolled round & another report is due from Scotter Settlement Indian School of this time I can say that I am satisfied as far as average attendance goes. It stands 28 for the month with 35 on the roll. That result is fair considering the season. I am greatly encouraged by the attitude of the parents toward me. Those who were most opposed to my "sharpness" being now my most earnest helpers. Our school officer so practically out of business & at late "pupil unheard of. Indeed they annoy me by being on hand before I go over to ring the 5 o'clock bell. I am sadly in need of those promised seats. Since I came 5 desks & seats have been resurrected & temporarily fitted there to accommodate 10 pupils & still I am short of space & have to shift here & there when a pupil chances to be off for a day. The desks referred to were taken from the cellar of the house occupy & the seat being tacked on do not hold up & are consequently very uncomfortable & inconvenient. Everything I applied for has been received excepting the arithmetics & these we are much in need of as black board space is so limited. Thanks for liberality & I do not succeed now! The Department cannot be blamed. The children are delighted with the drawing books & paint but I can scarcely say that I am with their artistic effusions so far. Drawing is also a drawing card. The girls like it.
I sincerely believe they would rather quiet their breath than the singing in the morning & I would be grateful for a supply of suitable old fashioned school songs & hymns. The Melodies & Sacred Selections Nos. 1-2-3-4 are good. We have no musical instrument here, that is why I would like the old family music. A couple of chairs & table for cutting etc., also a bench for a class seat which would be gratefully received. We are progressing in Reading, Spelling, Writing & Arithmetic & an interest is being aroused in Geography but Grammar & Composition are hopelessly failures. Not knowing the language accounts so that I suppose & I am endeavouring to get the pupil to speak English to each other during school hours but that too is an almost hopeless effort, that is the bright side. And for the other, in your last reply you asked me to refer the Wabesee case to the Agent. I referred to the agent before I complained to you & got no satisfaction for doing so. I shall not quarrel with him & the only way to prevent doing so is to allow the Department to refer to him themselves. If the Agent had done his duty all along I should have had no reason to refer to him or any body else when I tell you that 27 of my pupils are in harm & some of them 15 years of age you have proof enough that what I have said is true. I have 2 pupils aged 10 & 12 respectively who have not been 2 months in school in their lives & both are healthy girls. Mr. Wabesee came to me the other day & complained that his boy was being ill treated away from school by a boy.
whom I had not heard until that moment (although I got my list in the agent's office) & who is I should say 12 or 13 years old. I saw him for the first time this evening. He is an adopted son of Joseph John. Wallace has moved over to Saugus but has left his little girl here to attend school. One boy is also in the neighborhood but does not come to school. The other is roaming as usual having been just one day in school this month. This Jerry John came on to the playground where our boys were having a game of ball after school & a small crowd went with him to the church shed. Pandemonium reigned until I strolled down to investigate. It was then I saw the boy for the first time. He is a bright looking little fellow with a withered (left) arm. Later in the evening the district officer called at the house & asked me to write upon concerning these 3 boys. Now I have done so & expect my hands of the whole business but I sincerely hope you will not allow these 3 to undo all that has been done here for certainly unless these are straightened the others will not stay straight. If you will send me a new register I shall send Mr. Burns' latest records to you & unless I am incapable of counting correctly you will find his returns & names & fabrications from beginning to end. My discipline were doomed by the Indians claiming about the attendance being so much greater. I took a look over his entries found just what I have said. Remember correspondence is strictly private but I am prepared to back up every statement made.
If it should become necessary to do so, however I would prefer spending my little day here in peace with the men but I wish the Department to understand that the trouble is none of my making. I am in for the "effect" but the "cause" dates away behind me or rather before. While I remain I shall do my duty conscientiously & honestly without fear or favour. I am looked on with disfavour simply because I have refused to allow this gross injustice to continue. I have too much sympathy for the poor children who are suffering now because it has gone on so long. The Indians are no fools. They understand the whole matter & know that they have been allowed to deprive their children of the only means of bettering their condition. They are a strange childish race, but you know them better than I. It was not my intention to write a book when I began but less might have served the purpose. Hoping I have not exhausted your patience I remain

Yours obediently,

Another quarter is passing at close & another report due to the Department. Everything in & about the school is running smooth. Attendance continues to improve in spite of some drawbacks. The aggregate for May until to-night is 698, which gives an average for 20 days of exactly 34.5.

I have really only 32 on my roll now for the Walbees & have moved over to Saugan & are attending there Mr. Schofield informed me today. Jerry John (the neglected) came regularly for 15 days, the 24th proved too much for him however & he is again wandering not having showed up since. I find with rather bright & docile on school but outside his record is not so savory. His language is bad & he is extremely rough at play. On the 2nd day of his attendance I was obliged to administer a dose that kept him in perfect order the remaining 13 of the 30 with him. I feel very sorry for the poor child little fellows will do all they will or for him provided he attends regularly, but I cannot allow him to come & go when it pleases him as the others would very soon be taking leaves out of his book.

This afternoon Mr. Joseph Cameron called to tell me that he is leaving the Reserve for the Summer that removes 2 more from pupils so my attendance will be lower for a while.
One little girl was removed last night on the 8th. Another left school very ill today. I fear she will not be long. More cases will be for consumption has her marked as a victim. I have a whose eyes should be attended to & several whose teeth are in dreadful condition. Their Dr. has not called since quite a while. We received Arithmetics, Music Books, Pogs etc. Thank you for promptness this time. I shall send old Regulator at end of quarter. Mr. Dehofffield spoke of seats today. Our room is certainly small but would the double deck with single deck really take less space? I have asked him to move the stove nearer the door & enclose it in fine screen, as it is at present, it is a menace to the health of all seated near it. Could you give me the exact space required by each deck? I much prefer the singles especially for these Indians. Take the case of the poor girl who was ill today. Her cough so bad & her breath worse yet another little girl is obliged to put up with both so we cannot afford to give her a seat to herself. If she is far from being the only one in that condition although she is the worst. However use your own judgment as you have had longer experience in that business than I. But I do know that very soon this building will not accommodate the families unless they die or more suddenly than might be expected. I can name over half a score who should be coming this time next year & not one here now will be ready for disposal by that time. There is a platform on which my clerk
is standing which could be removed also a small 2 x 2 cupboard in the corner which could be placed higher up on the wall or done away with altogether & a larger one by some will doubtless be added. This might necessitate a little fresh paint but the Dominion of Canada is good for that I believe on experiencing due consideration before commencing the improvement so that there may be no "repenting at leisure" necessary after the work is completed. It would be much better without the platform I have stated & the desk itself could be boarded up & some drawers or shelves placed underneath or better still a more modern affair could be put in & the old one transformed into a cupboard for copy books &c. Becoming practical &c &c. Am expect to view situation would be the proper move. Poor Mr. Selkirk knows nothing about the matter but he has a few stubborn ideas which are immovable. He seems very much afraid of starvation for the Department after his death & is carefully saving to & every chance he gets. What in itself is all right, I do not believe in waste any more than he does but when I am talked at as if I ate too much disposed of them in some other nutritious way. I begin to feel restless & want to have a little room in my way but I may be obliged to squall the agent instead of brooms in order to get it. I wont quarrel with times don't fear that you remember the old definition of a line that is only there is precious little length either. I express my sincere only to the Dep't however who likely know him better than I.

Yours Respectfully,

Dear Sir,

Another month has rolled by & I had almost forgotten my promise to write; perhaps because I had nothing particular to grumble about. The stable is under way but I fear it will not be finished this year. Seats are at last installed & although not satisfactory must be endured, I suppose.

The work I thought of taking up with the boys cannot be carried on in double seats so I shall have that much less to think of. I wish to be allowed to purchase some more material for girls' sewing. We have a number of small chaps just beginning & these will only be able to them for some time. Handkerchiefs are always in demand. That is the easiest also for beginners. I also require some more flannelette. I would like to have material also for a few dainty aprons &c &c &c

I would like to prepare some work for exhibition next fall. Kindly permit me to choose this. The girls are all eager to "try" for a prize.

We are making fair progress in all our studies. Grammar expected. That helps me, I can do nothing with them beyond saying, "Don't say this or that." They do not know enough English to distinguish one kind of word from another.

The store has been facilitated on a kind of basis. It is certainly a smoothly botched piece of work. The pump & one house are still untouched.

This last quarter has been a record breaker for attendance. Our average was almost 30 (Thirty-three) thirty-four are most uncommon. I am obliged again to
call to your recollection the case of Jerry John. Your Agent tells me that he has represented him to you as being physically unfit to make his living even with an education. That is not the question as he is he is little better than a wild beast. I have had him in school for a few days & have found him brighter than the ordinary Indian child. He cannot read, he writes what he knows in excellent style. In arithmetic he is quick & fairly accurate, & why should he be allowed to do as he pleases? He is a thief & house-breaker by reputation already & will not likely be anything else unless taught something different. His adopted parents do not attend Church. He is just sent to Sunday School even & besides all that. Other Indians think if Jerry is allowed to do as he pleases their children should be also. I believe that a fine or two would make the matter all right. My Tenant Officer will not go after him. He is afraid of his father. The Department are morally responsible for the future of that boy. Please ask you to look after him.

Two of our brightest pupils have very defective eyesight & a number of them suffer very much from tooth-ache so it only duty to request the Dr. to call at the school & attend to these. I have spoken of them many times to the Agent, but have never had an opportunity of interviewing the Dr. Kindly advise me what course to pursue. The books I asked for are ordinary library books but I cannot give you the prices as I have no catalogue here. Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

Another month is nearing its close. Have delayed answering your inquiries re. Public School Library in order to carefully consider the proposition. The use of a few good books containing simple well-told stories would be a boon to the children. I asked some time ago to have "Canada Birds" & "The American Wild Animals" also "Our Domestic Animals" all illustrated, sent to me. You wrote asking price etc. That I could not give then nor can I do so now. I sent for some catalogues but these do not appear to be catalogue Books, these & pictorial books would greatly aid my pupils in understanding my meaning. They are fond of pictures & grasp ideas very quickly when presented in that form, but I find they may read a whole page & not get a single idea, that means they do not understand the language. I would advise getting in a few books carefully chosen, not too many at first, or with the understanding that they are to be used only in school.

I would not care to handle books that had been in some of the homes for even so short a time, besides few of the parents read. We have no place to put books & need a case badly. You would require to let me order that to fit our space. Our room is limited. We must very soon have an addition to the present building. If we ever had a basement, it would not be so bad. I have 35 pupils almost every day now & we have only about 17 x 24 floor space. I have had three illustrated works on other subjects & think they are $1.00 or $1.50. I forgot to mention Canadian wild flowers in same line of binding etc. We have the art series, and are certainly making use of them. As instructed I asked Dr. Williams to call. He did so & examined pupils & will forward report to you. The medicine he has sent to
me if I purpose giving it myself so as to be sure they get it. That will be all right, will it not? I judged from his remarks that his treatment will not kill the till. He found only 1 set of sound teeth in the mouth. Most of them are in a dreadful condition. One child is suffering from adenoids. Poor little creatures. Their inheritance is surely a sad one. If we could keep them away from these "Disease & Diet" infected homes, these people love their children, but they are murdering them just as surely as if they gave them a few grams of strychnine. The immorality is appalling. Here they appear to have good land & yet few raise even the potatoes they require. Two or three in each section work. These have well fed, well clothed children & they pay their debts but the majority live from hand to mouth. Never a stick to be seen round their doors & their poor cattle roaming the fields day & night. Winter Summer little food & less shelter. Their children barely better off than few of their houses are ruined. I firmly believe the principal reason for their regular attendance at school is because they are comfortable while there. I have inspected all their shoes at least being kept in good condition and tried to advise them when in need of new clothing to purchase flannel & I must say they are in rather better shape this winter. But I may as well not grumble. I worry of worse & this shake myself & wonder if it's worth while. I know I'm green at this business still & cannot drown the thought that there is a "more excellent way". I have no reason to grumble about attendance. My average for this month is almost 81 notwithstanding bad weather.
I am now preparing for a Xmas entertainment that is taking a great deal of time & interfering sadly with our programme. Still I believe in the end we will be gainers, i.e., if they keep all the promises they have made.

Application for me after Xmas vacation.

The Rev. Dept. Indian Affairs Ottawa

Dear Sir,

Some time before Xmas vacation I asked you to send my check for quarter's salary to Stratford. I did not receive it nor have I yet done so.

On Dec. 22 P.M. I filled out the enclosed reports & as I left by train at 6 A.M. on 26th gave them to Miss Skurrell to deliver to the agent. She received them on the following day.

The lady to whom they were given having evidently forgotten them. On Saturday 6th they were returned to me with the note enclosed.

I have tried to find out the error but have failed. I taught every day during the term excepting the two days associated with Thanksgiving Day. I cannot make 65 days in my school. In Oct. there were 22 days & I taught 19. The three holidays occurring in that month, Nov. 22 days & I taught every day in Dec. 16 & I also taught on all of these 22 + 22 + 16 = 60 according to my addition.

And of these my school was open 57. My pupils were there every day also. I am sending the whole fabric directly to you first as it stands. Advise me if I am wrong. I have filled out a good many school reports & have never had one returned until now. The failure to receive my hard earned check has caused me a great inconvenience besides the loss of interest as I had promised it to a party who was willing to pay a high rate for a small loan.

Here I am 44 miles from P.O. even & 6 from any Bank. With snow a couple feet deep it is impossible to reach work.
The P.O. cannot entrust money letters to Indians while neighbors are still away. Put yourself in my position and then say whether it is fair to be treated with such evident suspicion. I am a conservative and have endured unfair treatment from your agent ever since the end of my first month here. I have made good there and am still doing so and do not intend to put up with it any longer. He knows that I have proved conclusively that he fears he has not done his duty. I had no trouble with the Indians. They were so kind to me. The pupils like their school. Our Board Officer has not had an order from me in months. My every duty is performed to the very best of my ability. I have more pupils than before, to work with than either of the other schools, indeed I believe almost as much as both together. Yet I do no more for it and have been treated most unceremoniously at every turn. The sole reason being because I choose to assert myself. Dear Sir,

Dear Sir,

In reply to yours of May 21st, I beg to state in reference to the case of Jerry John that I certainly am not prepared to go before a judge & give evidence. As you know, I only had charge of this boy for a few days. He was then taken to Cake Croker by his foster-parents. After his return I tried repeatedly to have him compelled to come to school. I had no trouble in managing him & he certainly was quite bright & could learn apparently with ease. His deformity did not prevent him from writing or doing any work at his seat, about his capability in arithmetic I cannot now remember. However, that does not matter now. Since that time I have complained time after time when annoyed by him. Only last week a little 7 year old was off a day & a half in his company. His excuse when he came back was "Sick". I sent the Locust Officer to inquire & discovered that his parents knew nothing of his absence. Other parents have complained to me about Jerry meeting their children after school &c. &c. His language...
is dreadful as I am told, but remember I have not spoken to him since he left school. He invariably goes out of sight when he sees me. He has broken into several houses & has stolen repeatedly. I understand his foster father has no control over him. The boy was spoiled before I came here. I tried in every possible way to have him reformed. Had he been compelled to attend school regularly I would certainly by this time have acquired an influence over him. If Our Institute at Muncey has no room for him, they should be compelled to make room. Let the Agent & those who allowed this boy to become the nuisance he is, attend to this matter. I have done my duty strictly every moment since I took this situation & have been obliged to quarrel with the Agent in order to be able to do it. Jerry's perversity was not caused by any neglect & I am surprised at being requested to have anything to do with his reformation. I am sorry for the poor boy. He looks too good to be allowed to become a criminal. Still I cannot permit his influence to mar the good work I am doing here.
This is not "losing my own horn" at all. I have worked hard to bring my pupils to the point of appreciating their privileges & am only just beginning to enjoy the fruit of my labour. I had 36 pupils in school today. We have just passed through an epidemic of influenza which has lowered our average for this month but any school is liable to that kind of interruption. I have now 37 on the roll. There are still others old enough to come but I cannot take any more. We have seats for only 36. Our floor space is 17x24. We have air space of 5100 cubic feet. Only enough for 20 pupils. No ventilation system. Simply doors & windows. You will readily see that something must soon be done to provide accommodation. My pupils like to attend & certainly enjoy their studies. Our school is now well equipped in almost all lines & we are making good use of everything within reach. In a year or two we will be all white, not a vestige of Indians left.

About the library. Long ago you asked me to say what accommodation we had for one. At that time I rather discouraged your sending it as so few could read. Now it is different. They begin to want to know the end & beginning of the stories told in their readers.
Since becoming interested in Geography they also desire to know more about the inhabitants of other lands. I hope you will not disappoint us in this matter.

The picture of King & Queen has been received, thanks. I would like to get those of King Ed VII & Queen Alexandra also. We have Victoria. I understand that Mr. Burr had sent for the two I mentioned & that they were sent on to his new home & have not been returned.

This is all, I think, that it is necessary to mention this matter. I hope that you will take immediate steps to have something done with Jerry. He is surely an undesirable. Every day he is becoming more so & unless a halt is called will cause trouble.

Yours Respectfully,
Mrs. B. Roth.

Chippawa Hill, Ont.
Dear Sir,

Another month has passed & I herein submit my usual monthly report. Although I have sent several & as reply has returned & I am in ignorance of how they are received. Still as I agreed to send them without came here I, at least, will keep myself of the contract. My attendance during Jan was good by all excepting the pupils complained of in every report made during the year & also in my annual. I have decided that I shall not allow my work to be interfered with any longer by those pupils. They are only a hindrance & drawback to regular attendants. They come a day now & again & time has to be spent distributing books etc. At the end of the day every class is away behind with the usual daily routine. I have about 30 on whom I can depend to be in their places every day unless ill or detained by parents for necessary duties at home.

During Jan. the largest attendance for Monday was 18 & the lowest 24. Average for month 29.

With my cramped surroundings, large class etc. I am kept busy every moment of the day.

My school is becoming more like a White School than an Indian. The children are neatly & cleanly clothed; not merely outside but from the other out. They have good shoes, stockings, mittens etc. I insist on. I invite inspection any or every day by any important to judge.
My class will compare favourably with any white school in Bruce County or any other country school for that matter. My little children know more now than the grown-ups did when I came or do well for that matter for they are certainly a difficult proposition when allowed to remain in ignorance until 12 to 16 years of age. I will gladly do what I can for those (wild animals) deprived of the department to their part of see that they are compelled to attend with fair regularity. On the other hand unless they do I shall insist on their removal to some institution where they will at least be kept free from open vice.

The morals of this reserve certainly require a renovation to say the least. A little firmness would make everything right, at least openly & that is all that is done in even white settlements. Remember the Indians are not ignorant, they know their duty and know also when placed in authority over them do theirs. I know they do not like to be compelled to toe the mark, yet in the end it pleases them for they soon see result.

The Nakhkejee children & John Beattie's I again recommend to your attention. Fred Keeley's & Petahnequett's are influenced by these and are suffering in consequence. We have the whooping cough in our part of the reserve & so far bad weather in Feb so that our attendance this month may be diminished however all schools are liable to that kind of interruption. As far as the majority
Of my class is concerned, I do not care whether I get another truant officer or not. They come in all weathers and sometimes not very fit condition. There are little boys whose heads are half off with those dreadful sores on their necks. I question the wisdom of allowing them to attend but the little brothers in the same family are quite free from anything of the kind. Therefore, I reason that the rest of us will not be affected.

My school is kept clean and well ventilated. I get bottles of medicine from Dr. D., and administer it regularly with good results to those requiring it. Dr. Scott is a success among the Indians. He attends them care fully and advises them faithfully. I have only seen him twice but I know from others the good work he is doing. The bottles he has sent to my school have been just the cure for those requiring treatment. I wish he could be induced to attend to the teeth cases of my class. I have some bad cases of adenoid and only one good mouthful of teeth in the whole class. 3 cases also of defective sight require attention which I have reported ever since my advent.

I intend sending a photo of my class which I wish shown to every member of the Department from the Minister down. I think when they see what I have to mould into better citizens they will be convinced that it is worth while spending or being spent.

Yours respectfully,

Mrs. B. Robb.

At the close of another month I again submit my report. Attendance during this quarter has fallen off considerably. Shooting coughs what the children call "Sick teeth" being the principal cause. Their teeth are in dreadfully condition & when the weather is mild & wet as it has been the greater part of this winter they suffer from toothache & great deal. My aggregate was 508 of average 25. The lowest attendance during the month was 18 & the highest 30. I had 30 only for one day. I have a class here awaiting promotion into the 2nd Reader. Teacher
At the end of another month I submit my report. This has been the "dinner" month since my installation in Sept. Settlement School. There are 37 names on the roll. School was open 22 days being all the regular teaching days of the month. 18 pupils attended every day, 9 for 21 days & 4 for 20. The lowest attendance for any day during the month was 28 & the highest 35. The average for April is 33 1/2. Aggregate 736. Victoria Kukkuk has attended 4 days. Riley Kukkuk, not one. She has again changed her abode & has again caused the same disturbance going home from school. She is a vile creature, following closely in her mother's footsteps. She has been taken over to Saugan after being driven off from the mill & attended school there for a few days. Mr. Simon, their trusty officer, carted him back here last Friday evening because he had been stealing eggs & making himself a nuisance generally. I again ask that these two be taken charge of by the department. Certainly their mother is not a fit or proper person to care for them. She should be removed also to someplace where she would be obliged to work for her living instead of leading the horrible life she is leading & causing others to lead here. Of course that is I suppose, not in my line of business but nevertheless for the sake of the homes she is wrecking & the children she is despoiling I must do so. About the Trust Officer he has failed to comply with my demands & I refuse to acknowledge him as Officer.
Or to allow him inside my school until he does. He metted & interfered with me before the school & I require his apology to be made in the presence of my pupils. I also require him to sign a statement acknowledging his misconduct to the Department. I wrote & informed the Department at the time he transgressed. The Department never acknowledged my letter but some time after I received a communication asking me to make peace with the Agent Officer as I had been too peremptory in telling him to perform his duties. Let me now explain. I sent boys to his house 3 times asking him to go after those children twice he sent notes back saying he was sick. I waited each time until I saw him out of the house as usual & sent again. This time I heard nothing from him. I went on Saturday to Mrs. Scofield (Mrs. Scofield was too ill to be told) & she told me if he refused to do the work we would get someone who would. I sent him the note then which he evidently sent you. I'm not I said exactly what I meant by mean what I said. It was after that he interfered with the pupils in school & talked to me as he did. Because Mrs. Scofield was laid aside he evidently thought he could do as he pleased. He was instructed by the Chief & Agent to apologize. He came to my house before 8 o'clock one morning & I refused to hear him there & told him to call when the pupils assembled & that I would have the paper ready for him to sign. He never came back.
After my return at Xmas he, without any order, called at 2 places. At one of these it made no difference but the other (Fred Wesley) is a "touchy fellow" easily managed if he is honoured a little. I utterly arrange if rubbed the wrong way. His children were both ill (who could I had their fathers promise that they would be sent us soon as they were able to come. These children had not attended school previous to my becoming teacher here, one is 13 the other 9. I have encouraged ever since they came to school to keep on the right side of their father & have succeeded. They attend regularly & are usually first here in the morning although they live about 1/2 miles to come. Had I not heard of Mr. Moon's call on the very day he made it, I would have been minus one two pupils. I at once sent word to Mr. Wesley that Mr. Moon had no authority to go to his house & pay no attention to his call, to send his children when they recovered etc., they returned this month & have been here every day. My attendance is all that could be desired without the assistance of Mr. Moon. The dotted settlement children, as a rule, come to school because they like their school. The parents too careful not to keep them at home unless it is absolutely necessary. Those who are going to work have always done so. The Department must see to it that they are brought to time. My register & reports tell plainly who they are. The pupils who attend regularly are as anxious to learn as I am to have them do so & what is more they are learning very soon. My school will be white, poor.
Ottawa, May 15, 1913.

I have very bright pupils, badly handicapped by disease. One exceedingly bright and clever chap has adenoids and enlarged tonsils of the very worst type and although I had the Doctor come and examine the school and he sent his report to the Department, yet nothing has been done to relieve the trouble. This boy has stomach and kidneys affected badly from his head disability and I feel sure in a short time, unless prompt measures are taken, he will pass on to a higher school. OTTAWA, January 31st, 1922.

Madam,

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 21st instant, regarding those pupils in the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School who require operations for adenoids and enlarged tonsils, and in other cases, who require treatment for eye trouble, and glasses, I beg to say that the Department in July, last, took this matter up with Mr. Agent Stout with a view to having these children receive the proper treatment. At the time, Dr. Laird stated that he was unable to undertake the work, as he was not equipped with the necessary instruments, and also because there was not a suitable place to have the work done. The doctor stated that the Indian homes had no conveniences to take care of children after an operation, and the further consideration of this matter then dropped.

The Department has since learned that a specialist visits Southampton at different times, and it might be, if the worst cases were taken there, that the specialist would be able to perform the necessary operations and give the treatment required.

I would be pleased if you would give your personal attention to a consideration of the best means of arranging for the proper treatment being carried out in the cases of those children who are in the greatest need of a doctor's attention. If you would ascertain to date on which the specialist visits Southampton, and if he would perform any operations required, also the expenses that would be involved, and whether you could have the Indian parents take the children to Southampton, the Department would, when full information is received from you, be in a position to decide what should be done towards supplying medical attention in cases where required.

This matter may give you some trouble, but I am sure that, in the interests of the children, you will use your best endeavours to ascertain and inform me as to the best arrangement that can be made, and at the lowest expense to the Department.

As soon as your reply is received, we will then be in a position to further consider the matter.

Dear Sir,

I thought of us on this Reserve at all. You no doubt wondered why the delay in answering yours of Jan 31. Just a word explaining my surroundings here. I am living in the Centre Division of the Reserve, am between 5 & 6 miles from Station Town or Post Office. Have no Telephone or any means of communicating with outsiders unless by driving out. Being a Teacher Saturday is my only day available. Besides I live altogether alone. Have my school furnace, swamp etc to attend to. Have my own house, meals also keep a horse & a few pens that have to be cared for. I drive out every evening 1/2 mile for mail, milk etc so that in the short winter days it is hard for me to keep up. I also knew that it would not be possible to have anything done with these eyes, throat etc during the cold weather. We have had constant snow since before Xmas until this week. The sunshine is beginning to tell on the snow & once more the roads are almost bare. In the mean time I interviewed as many of the parents.

The girl with the quart eye, who entered my school in Oct 1916. Since that date she has attended at intervals 347 days. Sometimes a year between times attended. So you may judge how much she knows. She could read in first book Pt II, & write a little & when I tell you that that child who cannot be more than 13 is married you will understand that certainly a crime has been committed. The Agent informed me in Feb that she was married before Xmas.

The next eye case has been out of school since last fall. She had a stroke of some kind & could not walk but was otherwise fairly well. Just now she has been + is at present much worse, pains at back of neck &c. Fear she will not recover. I cannot say whether trouble was caused by eye strain or not.

The 3rd who is totally blind in one eye & has trouble with the other has been at Pickeral on North Shore since last fall but is expected home any day now. He is just requiring glasses. I think, is here + is backward on her school work. Suffering
much from headache & has a weary, drawn look on her face which is sad to see. She is a nice little thing & I have been hard on her believing her simply lazy & only recently discovered that her sight was at fault. You have Dr Laird's report & know what the throat cases are like, or rather were when he examined them. One boy has been out of school for 4 or 5 weeks, attacked on ship all winter has had a cold. It was simply wicked to hear him blow his nose (not a nice thing to consider about but it has to be done). I have 2 or 3 others almost as bad in that respect. I now shall tell you I am interviewing with Dr Laird last Saturday. He said that two specialists come to Southampton but not at any stated times, just when they are sent for or wish to visit. One is his brother Dr Laird & Evelyn. The other is Dr Parker of Toronto & I think this one has a summer home at Southampton Beach & is a regular summer visitor. Dr Laird had spoken to Parker about three Indian children & asked about cost of operation. His charge is $50 for a single case. But if a bunch could be operated on at one time he would only charge $10 each. It is Dr Laird's opinion that much of the eye trouble, dulness, lack of memory, stomach sickness, eruptions of the skin leading finally to tuberculosis in some form.
 
One of those who had been my pupils during the 11 years I have taught & who are now gone.

Actual deaths of those attending — 29
In one family I have attended — 4
Another — 2

So on... Only one family in Deitch settlement has escaped them. I taught 5 & all are alive.

How this compares with other Indian schools I do not know, but to me this seems a terrible death toll.

Many of these were very promising pupils as are many of those I have just now.
