MEMORANDUM:

ACTING DEPUTY SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL.

I beg to draw your attention to the very serious health conditions among the children on the Saugesen Reserve. These conditions were first brought to our attention by Mrs. Robb, teacher of the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, who is a very intelligent woman, and one of our best teachers.

We took this matter up with Mr. Agent Stout last summer with a view to arranging with Dr. C. J. Laird, the medical officer for the Reserve, to give the necessary treatment and to perform the operations necessary. Dr. Laird informed the Agent that he was unable to undertake the work as he was not equipped with the necessary instruments and that there was no suitable place to perform the operations required in the Indians' homes and no one to give proper care and attention and diet to the children after the needed operations were performed. The doctor stated that a specialist frequently visited Southampton, and that the worst cases might be taken there and attended to by the specialist.

In January, last, Mrs. Robb again drew our attention to the illness among the children, and she was asked to give her views as to the best means of arranging for the proper treatment to be given the children who were in the greatest need of medical attention. In her reply she gives a list of the various cases that require immediate attention, and suggests that they be sent to Southampton to be treated by the specialist who visits there occasionally. Mrs. Robb furnishes a statement of the deaths among the pupils in her school during the eleven years she has been teaching. She states that of the number who have been enrolled during that time twenty-nine have died.

I had today a personal interview with Dr. Clark, of the Department of Health, in this matter, and he stated that their Department would be prepared to send one of their specialists, Dr. Heagerty, to the Reserve to make an examination of the Indians and to furnish a report and suggestions as to the best means of treating the cases requiring the same. Dr. Heagerty's services would be given free, the only charge being for his expenses. In carrying out the necessary operations and treatments recommended by Dr. Heagerty, the Department of Health would be prepared to assist in the expenses, and if the cases requiring treatment are the result of venereal disease, they would be responsible for the entire cost.

As it is necessary, in view of the reports we have received regarding health conditions on this Reserve, that some steps be taken to give treatment, I would recommend that the offer made by Dr. Clark, of the Department of Health, to loan the services of Dr. Heagerty to examine these Indians and furnish a report together with suggestions for treatment, be accepted, and that I be authorized to request the Department of Health to allow us to utilize the services of Dr. Heagerty.

Mrs. Robb's (the teacher) letter regarding the cases requiring treatment is hereunder.

Sir,

Two of the officers of this Department interviewed your Dr. Clark regarding health conditions on the Saugeen Indian Reserve, more especially with reference to the need of medical attention for the children of school age on the Reserve.

The medical officer for the Reserve, Dr. C. J. Laird, Southampton, Ont., states that he is unable to undertake this work, as he is not equipped with the necessary instruments and that the Indian homes are not suitable places in which to perform operations, and that there is no one to give the proper care and attention and diet to the children after such operations are performed.

There are about 400 members, including men, women and children in the Saugeen Band. We are more especially interested in the health of the children than in the older members of the Band, who, in most cases, should be able to provide for their own medical treatment.

Having completed the schools on Friday afternoon, the agent, Mr. Stout, asked me to see a boy named Thompson who was absent from school and who had injured his foot. While examining this boy, I noticed that his little brother, who was nearby, looked rather pale and thin. I examined him and found that he was emaciated, was suffering from tubercular abscess in each axilla and, on examining his lungs, found that he was in the last stages of tuberculosis. He would probably live for another month or so. I examined Mrs. Thompson and found that she, also, was tubercular.

The agent then asked me to see Eva John, a former pupil of Mrs. Robb. This girl, although only 13 years of age, was married and deserted by her husband. She had had an eye removed some years ago. On examining
her I found that she was suffering from tuberculosis in a very advanced stage. She, also, will probably live another month or so. I examined her sister, Mrs. Nashkuaws, who was nearby, and found that she, also, was in the early stages of tuberculosis.

In driving along the road we met Luke Kewakuon who complained of a cold. On examining his lungs, I found that he, also, was tubercular. We stopped in to see another old Indian who was sick and found that this old man was suffering from pneumonia. He had had a visit from Dr. Scott about three weeks previous and had absolutely no attention. This completed Friday's work.

Saturday morning I was taken to see Hazel Williams. I found this child suffering from keratitis (inflammation of the eyes), probably syphilitic in nature. She had an old tuque pulled down over her head to shut out the light from her eyes. She was absolutely without medical care or attention of any kind, as her mother is dead and her father is alone. I examined her sister and found that she was suffering from opacities of the cornea of both eyes, which is evidence of old inflammation of the eyes. It is probable that this condition in both children is due to congenital syphilis.

I next saw Irene Nashkewa and found that this child was almost totally blind and, in addition, was suffering from paralysis of the left arm; this probably, also, the result of congenital syphilis. The agent then took me to see Karl Ritchie. This is an idiotic child who is subject to fits. I also saw Nora Joshua who requires to have her tonsils removed.
During my stay in Southampton, I interviewed Dr. Laird.* The impression made upon me by Dr. Laird was not a good one.* He impressed me as being addicted to the use of alcohol. Subsequent enquiries confirmed my opinion, that he is not a man in whom one could place much confidence. He stated, with regard to the operations for removal of tonsils and adenoids, that these operations could be performed during the month of June by Dr. Park of Hamilton, who summered at Southampton, that his fee would be ten dollars for each case and that, in addition, it would be necessary to provide an anaesthetist, (Dr. Laird himself) and nurses, whose fees were not specified. In addition, it would be necessary to provide a building wherein the operations would be performed, beds, bedding, hospital equipment, surgical equipment, hot and cold water, bandages and a physician to remain in attendance until the cases were convalescent. The whole thing to me seemed to be most impracticable and inadvisable.

I found that there is a bus service from Southampton to Owen Sound thrice daily. This bus passes through the Indian Village. The fare is ninety cents from the Indian Village to Owen Sound. I took the bus to Owen Sound. The bus is a modern motor bus, inclosed, with all modern conveniences and quite suitable for the transportation of well or sick individuals from Southampton to Owen Sound.

Arriving in Owen Sound I called on Dr. Geo. S. Burt, who is a specialist in eyes, ears, nose and throat. I had made enquiries at Southampton concerning Dr. Burt
and found that he was reliable in every way. I enquired his fee for removal of tonsils and adenoids and he informed me that his fee was $30.00. On explaining the nature of the cases to him, and the fact that there would be a number to be operated upon, he agreed to cut his fee to $10.00 a case.

He rang up the anaesthetist who also agreed to cut his fee of $5.00 to $2.50. The hospital fee for public patients is $.50 per day. Each of our patients would be obliged to remain in the hospital two days for the operation.

Sunday morning I visited the hospital and interviewed Miss McCarthy, the superintendent. I found that there was an operation fee of $4.00 for each case, but when the circumstances of the case were brought to the attention of the president of the committee in charge of the hospital, it was agreed to waive this charge. Therefore, the entire charge for each operation for removal of tonsils and adenoids would be as follows:

Bus from reserve to Owen Sound and return........$1.80
Dr. Burt's fee..................................$10.00
Anaesthetist's fee.................................$2.50
Hospital charge..................................$3.00

Total...............................$17.30

This rate is for five or more operations. Dr. Burt will also cut his fee in two for all eye examinations. These examinations are to be made in his office. The treatment of teeth can be carried out at Southampton and the fees
arranged for by the agent. I believe he has, at a previous date, made some arrangements concerning the matter. Should the Department consider these charges satisfactory and agree to have the operations performed, it will remain only for Mr. Stout, the agent, to obtain permission from the parents of the children to have the operations performed. The children can be sent over to Owen Sound in batches of five or more. The bus will accommodate at least ten. I was unable to carry out a more complete survey of the adult population, owing to the fact that ploughing and seeding are now going on and it was, therefore, impossible to see the Indians individually. It can be readily seen, however, that the health of the Indians on the reserve has been neglected. Tuberculosis would appear to be very prevalent and there would also appear to be a number of cases of syphilis. This does not augur well for the future of the Indians on this reserve.

Confidentially, I may say that I do not think either Dr. Scot or Dr. Laird deserving of confidence. Should it be necessary to provide a physician for the Indians, I think it would be better to bring one in from Owen Sound. One of the Owen Sound physicians, Dr. Miller, visits Allenford, which is a short distance from the reserve, twice weekly. It is possible that some arrangement might be made with this physician.

The above report is submitted confidentially.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of the report of Dr. J. J. Heagerty, dated the 16th instant, regarding the individual cases among the children on the Saugeron Reserve requiring medical attention, the operations or other attention required in each case, and the arrangement which he suggests should be carried out in order to have this work done.

In reply I beg to say that we are instructing our Indian Agent to act in conjunction with the teachers in order to have the necessary action taken to carry out the suggestions made by Dr. Heagerty in having those children who require operations sent to the hospital in Owen Sound, and in the cases where dental attention is required, to have a dentist from Southampton attend to the same.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

Re Medical Attendance for Indians of the Chippewa Band of Saugeen.

Agent Stout of the Saugeen Reserve was requested to inform the Department whether he considered that the Indians of that reserve have had adequate medical care during illness. This action was taken by your instructions and indirectly as the result of inquiry (by request of this Department) made by Dr. J.J. Heagerty, of the Department of Health, into conditions on the reserve.

In making reply Mr. Stout has stated that he considers that the Indians have not had the necessary care which has been necessary and he adds that they will not send for a doctor, especially in confinement cases knowing that they will have to pay for his services.

The agent recommends that the Department arrange for medical attendance for these Indians to be paid for on accounts. He states that if a salaried doctor is employed, he will be requested to render too frequent attendance, or to furnish services in cases of trivial ailments.

There are approximately 45 Indians in the band and considering that in the past many of them have been able to pay for a doctor's services, it is considered that if the Department undertakes to pay accounts for services and medicines up to $500.00 a year, the requirements of the situation will be met. The condition of the Band's Interest Account will admit of payment being made at this rate.

Agent Stout has remarked that Drs. Laird and Scott, of Southampton, who it is understood have furnished such attendance as the Indians requested, are reasonable in their charges, but Dr. Heagerty (as stated in Mr. Sutherland's memorandum hereunder of the 16th May) has reported confidentially that he lacks confidence in either Dr. Laird or Dr. Scott and has suggested bringing a doctor from Owen Sound. Dr. Heagerty is quoted as saying that Dr. Miller of that place visits Allenford twice weekly and could go from that point to the reserve. From an examination of the map of the country, it appears that a doctor resident at Southampton should be given the work. Allenford is four or five miles distant from the reserve and if a doctor is there only a couple of times a week, he might not be able to render prompt attention to the particular class of cases specially mentioned by Agent Stout.

I would suggest making a trial arrangement with Dr. Laird for six months, under which he should render attendance when necessary, it being understood that he be paid on accounts and

Dear Sir:

Since writing to you yesterday, regarding suitable openings in Indian day schools, I find that there is a vacancy at the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, which is 6 miles from Southampton, Ont., and 3 miles from the nearest post office - Chippawa Hill. Most of the children are of Church of England faith, but there is no church control over the school itself. There were 26 enrolled during the past year, with an average attendance of 17. The school house is a good, brick building, on a cement foundation. The teacher's residence is frame and is a 7-room house. Two Indians perform the duties of truant officer and janitor.

This post is really quite suitable for a married man, as there is plenty of accommodation. However, there is no reason why you would not be happy there. Of course, you would have to batch, but there would be plenty to occupy your attention, as you might want to make use of the rather decent barn that is on the property, where a horse and a cow could be kept.

Sir,

I wish to draw attention to official letter to you, dated April 26th, last, informing you of an increase of $10.00 per month in the salary of Mr. M. J. McIver, teacher of the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, as from April 1st, last.

In this connection, I now have to inform you that the Auditor General has drawn attention to a clause in the Salary Deduction Act, 1932, which prevents the granting of any salary increases during the current fiscal year. I regret, therefore, that it will not be possible to allow Mr. McIver any increase in salary over that he previously received, viz., $90 per teaching month, less 10% for the current fiscal year. This Department has no option but to comply with the demands of the above Act.

For the three months' period in the June quarter, Mr. McIver has received an over-payment to the amount of $50., less 10%, or $27. This amount will have to be deducted from his salary for the month ending the 30th instant. Please inform Mr. McIver accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

I have the honor to state my reply to your letter of the 31st ultimo that I examined the well at Scotch Settlement about a quarter of a mile from it. The well is twenty-five feet deep and the sides are stoned. Upon which, it measured six feet across but the walls are quite three feet thick which leaves a well hole of barely two feet across. Sir,

I have the honor to state in reply to your letter of 25 June 1897, that the erection of a dry earth water closet—double for the school settlement school according to the estimates that I have received were too expensive.

I therefore, in accordance with the wishes of the Indian Trustees, removed the old water closet to the extreme north-west corner of the school grounds & intend to use the dry earth. I also had the school grounds leveled, a new board fence put all around the ground, 3 new gates, 2 small, one 6th foot gate.

The foundations at the north-west corner, where the water had got in & the floor heaved it repaired, also 2 wooden pipes to conduct the water from the caves away from the building.

For leveling the ground I had it graded so that the fall from the school house all around is one inch per foot.

All the material used was new except the water closets. The gates had tin coated parts all well bolted, new hinges & new latches.

This work was let at a cost of $9 dollars, an extra of one dollar was asked for for building a 3 ft. plank walk from the steps atte

Sir,

I have the honor to state in reply to Letter of 27th inst. No. 163977/21 that there has not been a dry earth water closet built at the Scotch Settlement School, but the old one has been removed. I have instructed the Trustees & Teacher to account that the dry earth is used.

In explanation of having the work done without first furnishing the Dept. with an estimate of costs, I would say I tried to get offers to do the work of fencing & building a new water closet in accordance with plans received from the Dept.

I had different offers to build the fence the lowest of which was $32.00 but to build a dry earth water closet according to the Dept. plans double. Contractors would tell me that it might cost $36 or $40 but would not bind themselves to any definite cost therefore I had nothing definite to submit to the Dept.

This spring wishing to have the old closet removed from being in such close proximity to School House, I proposed to the Indian Council to use the old water closet but have it removed to a greater distance from the School House.

They at once passed a resolution appointing a day for one to go to the school grounds & explain to the Indians who gathered there the work to be done & let said work to the lowest bidder. As there was only three days from the time that it was proposed to have the work done in this way until the contract was let, it gave me no opportunity of submitting an estimate of costs to the Dept. I may say my estimate of the work done was $538.00

I have the honor to inform the Dept. that I visited the Scotch Settlement school the second day after the teacher Mrs. Robb returned after the vacation.

I found Mrs. Robb very much dissatisfied with the new seating in the Sch. Room. She found fault with the Dept. because the seats were not sent as she ordered them—that is, "36 single seats all medium size," as stated in my letter of May 9th last. She found great fault because of the different sizes which makes such a variation in the height of the desks.

I requested Mr. McKenzie to send her the seats placed as the teacher wished them on Sat. 9th inst., she sent 2 messengers and directed him to send them to raise the desks & seats to the height required.

When Mrs. Robb found that she could not place the seats to suit her, on the amount of floor space available, she refused to have anything more to do with the placing of them.

She then picked up her tools and went home.

I again visited the Sch. this afternoon and found Mrs. Robb as dissatisfied as ever. Nothing apparently will satisfy her.

Dear Sir,

Your communication dated Sept. 22 received. Am sorry to be obliged to again enter a protest against slant seats. They are still sitting on floor without fastening & have been and are a great annoyance to me. With regard to space, I had the stove moved forward over 4 feet which gives us a good center aisle & the platform removed from front which greatly increases our floor space. The reason I asked for single desks was because having taken up sewing, drawing etc. with my pupils, I had found it exceedingly difficult to arrange work satisfactorily on the double. I had also discovered that in order to prevent copying it was absolutely imperative that pupils occupy separate seats.

I had arranged (in my mind) the desks as follows:

1. Rows on outside close to wall & seats each.
2. With narrow passage between them & outside rows of 8 seats each then 2 wide aisles of a single row of 6 seats making on all 40.

I wanted 5 rows of 5 fronts & all to be the Ball Bearing Adjustable Desk No. 2, which can be adjusted to suit any pupil I have or am likely to have. These should be proof for generations & could be moved to any building that may have to be erected in the future. On the seats but there are 4 sizes, 6 of the very small (almost useless here), 6 a little larger, 3 still larger & 8 of the No. 1; nearly one half pupils seated on high seat with low desk in front, a very unhealthy position. The 3 rear are all high & there are no fronts. The connected seats taking up space merely. We have been unable to either write or draw during the months as the desks balance on center casting & are continually changing positions.

Our attendance has dropped away down. 4 of our Indian families are away pulling flax. There are 9 of our pupils in that bunch. Another family of 4 has measles so that although I have 37 names on register our average will be down to 22 or 23, perhaps even less. This is most discouraging. Those who are away are the very ones that give all the trouble when here, & certainly they do not better themselves financially by going. I have also to report no sign of new stable. Pumps not touched. Stone still unfinished & neither light nor air in my cellar all summer. Am here alone & am obliged to keep windows nailed as there is neither wash nor lights. Truly I am developing into a chronic humbler but not without reason. I shall not say anything about the book-binding material at present as I can do nothing with that until these deals are screwed down. I have to report a little on the bright side also. The children in attendance are beginning to speak a little English outside & are well behaved & obedient in school. They are much brighter & decidedly cleaner looking than when I first came among them. They are improving a little in every way. The great drawback is not understanding the language. It is not much trouble to teach them the words but it is very difficult to get them to grasp their meaning. There are a few books I would like to have, Canadian birds with coloured plates, Canadian flowers & Our Domestic Animals.

Yours Respectfully,

Geo B. Roth

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Public School Inspector McCool, in his last report on the Scotch Settlement Day School, states that the present building is altogether too small for the number of children in attendance and recommends that something should be done in the way of providing more room so that the teacher's work may be more effective.

The present school-room is only 25 feet by 24 feet, while the enrolment is 41 with an average attendance of 33. This does not give the required amount of floor space and the air space is far short of what the children should have. The school-house is an old brick building which might be enlarged, but it would be much better if a new building could be erected next summer. It is now too late to do anything this fall. The Saugeen Indians have plenty of money and I think that they might be induced to vote some funds for this purpose.

The Sec. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

I judge my progress made on my enlarged school building that it will not be ready for occupation for some time. I would like some provision made whereby my class may be assembled at the usual time. It is ruinous for Indian pupils to have too long holidays. I have so long insisted on having them on hand at beginning of term that I hope it may not be necessary to allow a departure from the usual regulation.

I have a good fourth class & you know how difficult it is to keep them after the period of enforced stay. I am sorry also that the whole basement has not been dug out. I had visions of a good room down there in which to teach domestic science. Yet the grilly expensive wind which they could never hope to use, but just the making of good bread & plain biscuits & pie. Also to give them a knowledge of putting down fruit & making pickles etc. They pick berries all summer, sell to store keepers who preserve them & then sell them back to Indians in the winter. In that way they get only a very little pay dear for it at that.

I would like to ask the Department also to furnish simple desks for at least the larger pupils. They draw large

Dear Sir,

I have received your letter and am very glad to hear from you. I have been busy preparing for tomorrow's lesson and have arranged for two good school desks. The desks I have used before have been satisfactory, but they are expensive. However, the school desks shown appear all right. If we could have 24 seats, the larger size would be more suitable for Indian children who are larger than ordinary pupils.

I think three rows of single desks would suffice, but two double rows would be too small for our pupils. The desks had to be elevated on wooden bases which rendered sweeping and cleaning difficult. I would not advise placing any of these small ones in the new room. The type we had were the single desk, which have very narrow backboards and very elaborate carving on the metal sides.

In reply to your question, I beg to state that I certainly did refuse to have the books, maps, etc., stored in my house. I know also that the party who informed you had done so in a way plainly intended to cause me trouble or will. The surprise indicated in your question I shall now give you my reason which I am sure will show that it was not done with any arbitrary motive.

I occupied my house this summer for the purpose of caring for my garden & premises generally. When the farmers were about, I also entertained my friends here during vacation. I certainly would not cook, eat or sleep where those dusty, germ laden furnishings were stored. The books have been stored there because the school for 5½ years & as quite a number are & have been 4th Class students. They have a number of books etc. each. Now at least of these pupils have sore necks. Sometimes positively rotten, 3 or 4 have sore eyes, & 2 or 3 have running ears. I have endured the combined odors in a room unventilated & unlawfully small 17x24 & having an average of over 30 as you know. Besides there were, at that time, 2 empty houses not more than 20 rods from the school; one across the road has been occupied for 4 weeks by a man who came here to work on the job & who has
Now moved back to his own home. The other is in the same field as the school yard & has been empty for about a year & likely to continue so for some time. My own house is not in a fit state to occupy as it is. Two years ago I asked to have the kitchen, pantry & a room upstairs papered. Nothing came of the request & I shall not ask again. The paper on both kitchen & pantry is hanging in disgraceful condition. We have strapped & tacked it up as well as we can. When it becomes impossible to do so any longer I can go home. My house & furnishings are still in my possession. The only furniture we brought here were the piano, sewing machine, a brass couch-bed, & our trunk & clothing so it will not be difficult to move back if we are obliged to. I do not ask for anything until it is really necessary & do not take a "let turn down" with good grace, especially when others on the staff appear to get repass when asked for. I am doing my duty as faithfully as any of them & deserve at least the same consideration. I hope to see some members of the Department here when this building is finished & they can then see for themselves just how things are.

Yours respectfully,

Mrs. B. Noble.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR MCCOOL ON THE SCOTCH SETTLEMENT SCHOOL.

Two or three benches for the basement

If single desks could be put in, it

had a splendid school erected and deserves the sincere gratitude

Date of Inspection,-October 31st, 1916.
Ottawa, November 7, 1916.

Memorandum for

Mr. Scott.

As instructed I made an examination of the Teachers' Residence in connection with the Scotch Settlement School, with a view of making the necessary repairs to the building for which requests had been made. The kitchen is erected as a wing and has become separated from the main building breaking the plaster and permitting the cold to enter the building. The wall paper is nearly all off the walls and ceilings of both kitchen and pantry and as one of the walls of kitchen (side of main building) is of wood battened and painted, I have instructed the Agent to repair the plaster after removing paper and to paint the walls as this treatment will prove more durable than the paper under existing conditions. Repairs are also necessary to the chimney and the Agent has been instructed to have these made while the contractor is at the school where he has the necessary materials for doing the work.

The walls of this building where covered with iron siding are showing signs of wear, the metal showing through the paint which will soon rust through unless painted early next season on the arrival of favourable weather.

The boundary fence between school and residence is in bad condition as stated in the school report and the Agent authorized to make the necessary repairs thereto.

Architect.
Ottawa, November 7, 1916.

Memorandum for Mr. Scott.

On October 28th I made an inspection of the new Scotch Settlement School the contract of which is now nearing completion.

The building is of solid brick construction on stone foundation with basement (under new portion) furnace heated and ventilated in a satisfactory manner. The interior of the building is completed except the placing of black-boards, and the exterior with the exception of painting and grading around the building which has been delayed owing to the constant wet weather there which would not permit of this work being done satisfactorily.

The completed work is first class in every particular as far as can be judged from inspection in a finished condition without personal knowledge of the work under construction.

The class room accommodates 40 to 45 pupils and is well lighted, heated and ventilated. The hardwood floors are oiled and varnished in a sanitary manner. The two cloak rooms for the sexes are also floored in hardwood and the trim finished in oil and varnished as is the small teachers' entrance room. The ceilings throughout are of metal neatly tinted.

There is a staircase to basement giving entrance from both out and inside with locked doors which permits of the basement being kept in a sanitary condition without entering the school room etc. while doing this work.
The fences and grounds surrounding school require some attention as some of the fence posts have rotted away allowing the fence to fall, and the yard requires some grading and ploughing. I have instructed the Agent to have these put in order, also to provide a few loads of gravel immediately surrounding the school entrances.

The pump platform was found in bad condition with flow of surface water towards the well. The Agent has also been instructed to take off the defective wood platform and build up in concrete extending the wall of concrete at least 4 feet below the surface to prevent frogs, toads and worms entering the well.

When these repairs have been completed the school and surroundings will be first class in every particular.

The equipment of this school is deficient to the extent that 43 pupils are enrolled with seating accommodations for 36 and for 4 of these the seats and backs are not the required size for the desks, the seats being so high that there is no space to permit the scholar to occupy the seat with comfort. New backs of the proper size should be provided.

The additional 7 single seats required can be taken from the village school, Saugeen Agency, which have a large excess of seats over their requirement and of the size necessary.

A desk and chair for the teacher is also necessary and should also be provided as the ones now there are useless for the purpose.

Architect.

EXTRACT FROM THE QUARTERLY RETURN OF MRS ROBB, TEACHER OF THE SCOTCH SETTLEMENT DAY SCHOOL.

June quarter, 1917.

Our beautiful school is being ruined by water standing continually in the basement. The furnace, doors etc are rusting badly.

DEPT. OF INDIAN AFFAIRS,
JULY 11 1917
ARCHITECT.
Ottawa, July 27, 1917.

Sir,

Mr. Abraham in a recent report stated that water was seeping into the basement of the Scotch Settlement school from the higher ground in the rear of the building, and Mrs. Robb in her report on the school for June, also states that the water is standing continuously in the basement of the school causing the furnace to rust badly.

I have, therefore, to request that you will have a drain dug at the rear of the school extending along each side to the front and thence connected with the drain from building towards the road. The drain should be about three feet away from the building and at least one foot below the basement floor and filled with small stones and gravel for a depth of one or two feet so as to intercept the water from hill and allow this to flow to the drain from building.

This work should be undertaken at once and completed as economically as possible.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

T. A. Stout, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill, Ont.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR COOL ON THE SCOTCH SETTLEMENT SCHOOL.

The building is new and very fine. The basement has not yet been properly drained, hence the iron of the furnace is very rusty. It would be very advisable to have the basement thoroughly drained before the wet weather of fall sets in. It would be a pity to have such a fine school and furnace spoiled because of the water on the cement floor.

Closets seem clean enough but they have not been emptied during the summer, nor have they been whitewashed and there is one case of diphtheria in the settlement.

October 9th, 1916.

Kindly inform the Department if you have been able to secure labour to dig the drain. The Inspector states that this is urgently required.

Sir,

Mrs. Robb, teacher of the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, in a requisition which she forwarded for supplies, states as follows: "Our school was entered sometime ago and erasers, pencils, lead pencils, crayon boxes, erasers, paint boxes, etc., taken wholesale and every key belonging to doors excepting the one I had at home. A broken basement window let thieves in. Window pane still out or rather part of it."

I shall be pleased to hear from you as to the result of the inquiries which you make with a view to ascertaining the parties who entered the school.

Sir:

The teacher of the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, in her report for the current fiscal year, states that there is water in the basement of the building every spring for a period of from 3 to 4 months. I have to request that you will forward a report as to the cause of the water entering the basement and what you would suggest be done in order to provide proper drainage facilities. Please state the approximate cost of any work you would recommend be done in order to prevent the water from remaining in the basement. A full report will be expected at an early date, giving as full particulars as possible, as well as the cost involved, in providing drainage for this building.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Skul Putnam, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill,
ONT.
Sir,

I have the honor to refer to your letter 31-3-5 of March 30th.

I wish to say that this report is greatly exaggerated. There is some water in the basement, but for it being there three or four months is not true. I think the cause of the trouble is it leaks through the foundation at the floor. I have been paying particular attention to this basement all winter, but could never find out where the water came in, and Mrs. Robb herself cannot explain it.

There is a drain from the bottom of the basement on the south side of the school running south for about a hundred and thirty feet. There is another drain on the outside along the north and west side of the foundation and empties into the drain running south. Mr. Besito who did the work was in the office last night, and he informs me that the north and west side of the foundation on the outside are plastered with cement, and this extra drain put in, and still the water comes in.

I have men working at it at present, and Mrs. Robb was well aware that I was going to do this work when she wrote the Department, as you gave me authority in your letter 31-3-5 of December 30th. I had men working when I received your letter of March 30th. I am cleaning out the bottom of the drain on the south side, but if this will help matters, but if it does not, the only way I know of would be to plaster the inside of the basement wall with cement, putting in a new floor of cement, raising the floor from the north, west and east sides, so as the drain would run out of the south side. The floor of the basement has none if any fall to the drain. I think the drain running south from the school was never put in properly, for the south end drain should take the water away off the floor, and also from the drains from the outside. I think this drain will have to be taken up, and put in larger tile, as I notice it is falling in, in some places. With regard to the cost, I think it would cost about one hundred and fifty dollars to do the job properly.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

EXTRACT FROM JUNE QUARTER RETURN OF THE SCOTCH SETTLEMENT INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

We have had sickness principally among large pupils caused largely by foul air from basement coming in through cold air pipe which was open all winter. Basement under water for four months in which was soaking and moulding bark and dirt from several cords of short wood thrown in at different times from February until end of April. Basement requires thorough renovation, whitewashing, etc. Schoolroom also must be thoroughly cleaned this holiday. Pumps are both out of order at present. Fence also... We have no flagpole. Where attendance was regular progress has been good, pupils willingly doing work assigned. I would ask that David Thompson be not allowed to leave his family of 6: 4 boys and 2 girls; ages from 14 to 6 alone here, while he and his wife go around country peddling baskets and begging. I ask this for sake of girls. Charlie John is nearly always away from home. He takes his family but they are neglected as far as education is concerned. These neglected children keep others back and take too much of my time from the others. Notice their ages and standing in school.

Mrs. B. Robb, Teacher
Sir,

In reference to the enclosed report I beg to report as follows:

Mrs. Robb taught on June 23rd and school was closed on Friday June 26th. She did not teach on June 30th and I think that she should not be paid for it.

The cold air pipe was slightly damaged by children throwing wood in the basement for Mrs. Robb's convenience, but the pipe was not open.

There is some water in the cellar at times but there is a good woodshed and this wood should not have been put in the basement. The school is built on a springy hill and it would cost considerable to drain the basement.

Charles Johns was away from the reserve for about a year and I had a letter from a teacher near Markdale certifying that the children had attended school regularly.

As to Mrs. Robb's report of sickness I wish to say that I admit that there has been less sickness during the past year than for many years.

In conclusion I might say that Mrs. Robb is caretaker of her school and the pupils do practically all the work and she gets the salary.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Sir,

I have the honor to refer to enclosed quarterly report for Scotch Settlement school. This report is greatly exaggerated.

Regarding the health conditions I have never had a report of any epidemic of any kind of sickness in Scotch Settlement. We had an epidemic of whooping cough in the Village, but there wasn't any in Scotch Settlement. Regarding the boy, who she says is literally dying on his feet, Mrs. Robb has never informed me of this case, and I do not know who the boy could be. Neither do I know why the four girls are that she mentioned have goitre. The girl she mentions who is blind in one eye is Mary Cameron, who was in the hospital in Owen Sound from April 14th to June 27th under the care of a specialist Dr. Hurt, and he didn't recommend glasses, and he ought to know better than Mrs. Robb whether she needs glasses or not.

With regards to water in the basement, I don't know how there could be any, as there was a drain put in this summer, one of the best, that I ever saw in a cellar. It was put in with six inch tile. Mr. Parker examined this drain when he was visiting the reserve last fall, and I think he will back up my statement. I visited this school on the 22nd inst. and Mrs. Robb did not mention any water in the basement. She did not make a complaint of any kind, and it is the only time since taking this office that I was up there without Mrs. Robb having a complaint of some kind.

Re the pump, she had been complaining of the pump, and last month there was some glass to be put in, and the bell to fix, and I took a man up, an expert, I went up with him, as he would need help to lift it out, and he said there was nothing wrong with it. She sent word to me with the truant officer that the pump was not working.

Re the house cleaning, I wish to refer to your letter 14-31 of May 16th, 1924, where you said Mrs. Robb was caretaker, and it was up to her to keep the school clean. Her salary was raised at that time for that purpose. It would be impossible to please this woman, and she has had trouble with every agent who has been here in her time.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

In reply to yours of Jan. 5th, I hereby state the names of pupils asked for. The boy Elijah Thompson age about 13, son of David Thompson, an almost blind man, who has a family of 6 children, 4 girls & 2 boys to provide for. These are all attending school except the youngest child, a boy. Elijah had a severe sickness about a year ago, since when he has been apparently anaemic seldom strong enough or too listless to join in the games of the others. He is very, very thin, lips & ears colourless, gets up & sits down like an old man & certainly requires more nourishment than he is getting to enable him to recover.

The girls are named in order of apparent progress of the disease.

Mabel John, age about 10, large lump on right side of neck, very dull, cannot remember anything, is thin and troubled with sore eyes.

Jeane Thompson, also 10, lump on right side neck, pale & thin but lively enough & doing fairly well at school.

Elijah Thompson, age 14, neck enlarged on both sides otherwise in good condition.

Dinah John, half-sister Mabel, about 7, growth on one side of neck showing as Mabel's appeared 2 years ago. The Thompson girls are sisters of Elijah, the delicate boy. I also have a little boy here who has a very bad ear, this week it has been again discharging a watery fluid which drops on his clothes. This occurs whenever he has a cold, looks quite miserable.

Another boy, age about 8, has been out of school for some time suffering from enlarged glands & stiff swollen neck.

I do not know what is the matter. He is the last of a family of 6. Two boys died of consumption & two girls & boy of this. Mother dead also & this little man looked after by his aged grandmother.

These Indians appear to be very scarce of money this winter & a number of children are certainly undernourished. A school nurse or doctor should visit them occasionally. Other schools have regular attendants who advise parents & teachers so that existing wrongs may be righted.

About that basement.

The work put on that ditch was, as far as I am able to judge, positively useless. A larger tile & little deeper ditch at south side of school was all that was changed & since fall rains that ditch has fallen in about a foot & lies ready to hold surface water to make matters worse. Since school was built in 186 we have had water in basement. Two large water pipes from cisterns at west end of school pour their contents above ground & water or ice is there whenever rain falls or snow melts. The wall at North West corner was wet from top to bottom two months ago & since then we have water lying in basement. When I came here after vacation I spoke to Chief Solomon, who did the work, about the necessity of extending those water pipes down into the tile along bottom of walls. He said he had spoken to the Agent about it but the agent refused to change his plans. So there the matter ended & here the water lies as usual & I do not see that the larger tile has carried off any more water & I know that the party who supplied tile made 3 trips here when the whole thing should have come in one.
About the Pump.

Whoever said that there was nothing wrong with the pump certainly said what was not true. Since the pump was put in, it worked perfectly until Sept. 1924. It is an iron pump and so constructed that it cannot freeze in cold weather and it has not frozen at any time. But the pump has worked loose and rattles round every time the handle is used and has had to be primed every morning and several times during the day since Sept. 1924. Never before that. This priming business when performed by sometimes not very clean Indians is to say the least not appetizing and this has had to be done winter and summer. In winter when weather is frosty, ice gathers on the pump until boiling water has to be used for priming. The agent brought a man here but snow and cold were here and I know they did not look into the well to examine the pump, probably the pump did not require priming at that particular moment. However, that can no figure for the agent has been told repeatedly about the trouble.

Yours Respectfully,

B. Robb

Dear Sir,

In obedience to your request I today visited the Scotch Settlement School and examined the children you asked me to examine. I numbered them and briefly mentioned their ailments and indicated the line of treatment for each under his report.

Suitable medical treatment will meet the present needs of each.

I do not see that there is much if anything you can do to correct their trouble.

Your truly,

C.J. Laird.
1. Elijah Thompson, aged 13. Pulse 76 Temperature 98°F. Free from disease, anaemia and listlessness due to malnutrition. Treatment: Better food, milk, eggs, nuts, etc., of which he gets. Blood enriching tonics.

2. Mabel John, aged 10. Pulse 75 Temperature 98°F. Has a large goitre. Naso pharynx is unhealthy, otherwise fair physical condition. Treatment: Suitable goitre remedies.

3. Irene Thompson, aged 12. Pulse 76 Temperature 98°F. Has a small goitre. Treatment: Goitre remedies.

4. Ellie Thompson, aged 14. Pulse 76 Temperature 98°F. Well-developed girl. Has a small goitre. Otherwise healthy and normal. Treatment: Suitable goitre remedies.
5. Dinah John, aged 7. Pulse 116. Temperature 100. The elevated temperature and increased pulse rate are due to the presence of a slight degree of acute tonsillitis.

She has a small sized guitar and enlarged tonsils. Her teeth are in bad condition. Dental treatment is needed. Pain remedies for guitar.

6. Ernest John, aged 7. Son of Mr. Savage John, is undersize. His left ear is discharging. He has a pharyngitis and adenoids, and is poorly nourished.

Removal of adenoids, better food and tonics to improve his general health is the treatment for this boy.
7. Peter Petahnequott aged 8 son of James Petahnequott was absent from school so I had not the opportunity to examine him.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing the report of Dr. Laird on his examination of the children who require medical attention at the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School. We note that the Doctor states that suitable medical treatment will meet the present needs of each case. It is hoped that he will see that the children who have goitre receive the necessary treatment and remedies. If a small quantity of iodine salt was supplied, and the necessary instructions given the teacher, she would, no doubt, see that the same is given, as prescribed by the Doctor, to those pupils who have goitre.

It is also considered that if those pupils who are undernourished would receive milk it would be of benefit to them. The teacher would, no doubt, see that they get a moderate supply each day. You might arrange to have the amount required delivered to the teacher at the school, and she should see that the children who require same receive a small quantity each day. Please consult the teacher regarding the serving of the milk, and inform the Department as to the number of quarts you would recommend be delivered, and the cost per quart. If any utensils are required for the serving of the milk, the same could be obtained after you have forwarded the Department a list of what is required.

Please take up with the Doctor and the teacher as soon as possible the question of supplying iodine salt, and milk, and inform the Department definitely as to whether you would recommend that the above suggestions be carried out.

Extract from Report of Inspector McCool on the Scotch Settlement Day School - dated October 1st, 1926.

The school and dwelling are in one building. The cold air pipe of the furnace is in two parts and the air in the basement and hallway going down is very foul. The cold air pipe should be fixed at once as this cannot be healthy for the children.

The pump is very hard to work and requires priming. It does not seem nearly as easy to operate as the former pump.

The inspector noticed that some of the children had not any great nourishment for dinner. In cold weather and in winter time, a hot lunch would be a great blessing here for the children. The children would be attracted to the school and their study would be improved.
Ottawa, October 13th, 1926.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McCool, in a report on his recent inspection of the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, states that the cold air pipe of the furnace is in two parts, and that the air in the basement and hallway going down is very foul. He recommends that the cold air pipe be fixed at once, as, under the present conditions, it is not healthy for the children. Please enquire into this matter and arrange to have any repairs required to place the cold air pipe in a satisfactory condition.

The Inspector further states that the pump is very hard to work and requires to be primed each time it is used. Please examine this pump and arrange to have any repairs or alterations made in order to put it in good working order. The Department will expect you to attend to this matter at an early date.

Any expense incurred should be kept down to the lowest possible point, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded by you covering the cost.

Last winter, as you are aware, two quarts of milk per day were supplied for the children. The Inspector recommends that the pupils receive some nourishment at lunch time. Please report as to whether you can arrange to obtain this quantity of milk each day and have it delivered to the teacher to be given to the children. If Mrs. Robb, the teacher, would prepare and serve hot cocoa at lunch time to the children, the Department would be prepared to authorize the purchase of the supplies required for the purpose. You might ascertain from her whether she would prepare and serve this drink and advise the Department. Your early reply is requested.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I have the honor to inform you that in the past the pupils of the Scotch Settlement School have not had their school garden in connection with the school but have taken the school seed home and planted it in the family garden; in this way only a few of the pupils receive seed and get the benefit of the garden which should belong to the school in general. As there is a considerable strip of land in connection with this school and Teacher's dwelling which is not being used, I would suggest that a plot of this ground be cultivated and used as a school garden so that every pupil could have an equal interest in it. Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my visit of inspection to the Saugeen Agency.

SCOTCH SETTLEMENT SCHOOL:

Attendance is very good. The day I was there 26 pupils were present out of a roll of 30. The classroom was very tidy and clean. The pupils were bright and happy looking. Very satisfactory progress is reported here. The school property is in very fair condition. The closets need jacking up and new sills put in. The school needs painting both inside and out. The closets should also be painted at the same time. The ground in front of the school is very rough and uneven. The hay was not cut this year. At very little cost it could be plowed up, levelled and seeded down. This would add very much to the appearance of the property. The grounds cover about three acres. The fences need some new posts and the wire stretched and stapled.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his recent inspection of the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, states that the closets need jacking up and new sills should be put in; also that the school building needs painting, both inside and outside, as well as the closets. He states that at very little cost the grounds could be plowed up, levelled and seeded down, and that this would add very much to the appearance of the property. He also states that some new posts are needed in the fence and that the wire should be stretched and stapled.

26 pupils present at 9:30 on the day of my visit. Attendance has been very good, averaging 25 out of a roll of 28 for the month of April. Discipline and deportment in the classroom was very good. The classroom is bright and airy, and well scrubbed. A school garden was being prepared for planting.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his inspection of the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, states that both closets and screens should be jacked up and straightened, and a coat of paint applied, and that the door of the boys' closet needs reconditioning. In this connection I would refer you to official letter of November 17th last. The Inspector also recommends that 5 new window blinds be supplied for the windows in the classroom.

In this connection I have to say that you should arrange during the coming summer holidays to have the closets thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good, sanitary condition. The screens should be repaired. You may also arrange for the purchase and installation of 5 new window blinds for the windows of the classrooms. In carrying out the above work, you should keep all expenses as low as possible, and you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Inspector has further recommended that the school building, both inside and outside, be painted. In this connection I have to say that we will have no funds this year for this work.

Regarding the grounds, which are stated to be rough and uneven, I shall be pleased to have a report from you as to what you would recommend be done in having the grounds levelled, and the approximate cost of the work.

You may arrange, if the work has not already been attended to, to have the fence repaired and any new posts put in and the wire stretched and stapled, forwarding the usual certified accounts covering the cost.

Inspector McGookin recommends that a softball for the girls, 4 pictures for the classroom and a 9' flag be supplied. It is considered that, as the school will soon be closing for the summer holidays, the supplying of this equipment could stand over until the school reopens, at which time you might forward a requisition for same.

A supply of forms for teacher's report of absences and for truant officers will be sent under separate cover.

Scotch Settlement School:

Teacher; Mr. M. J. McIver. Progress very good, attendance excellent, a number of pupils have perfect attendance marks. Classroom well scrubbed, tidy and thoroughly ventilated. Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his recent inspection of the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School, states that the boys' closet needs a new top and the door rehung, also that a urinal should be installed. He also states that the back porch is breaking away from the main building and that it requires to be jacked up and the foundation strengthened.

I would request that you arrange to have the repairs required made to the boys' closet and a urinal installed at an early date. You should also arrange to have the foundation of the back porch strengthened and the porch jacked up and placed in good condition. All costs for the above work should be kept as low as possible and, when same has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Inspector has drawn attention to the condition of the double seats, some of which he states are in poor condition. He states that at the French Bay Day School there are 12 good single seats piled in the back of the classroom which are not in use, and recommends that they be transferred to the Scotch Settlement School. I have to request that you will arrange to have these single desks transferred from the French Bay School to the Scotch Settlement School at an early date. The Department will pay any costs involved in the transfer upon receipt from you of a certified voucher covering the expenditure incurred. Please arrange to have the desks transferred at an early date.

Dear Sir:

INSPECTOR'S REPORT

Scotch Settlement Indian School. Date of Visit P.M. Oct.26,1938.
Post Office address of school....Chippewa Hill.

Teacher...Malcolm McIver.

A splendid lot of vegetables was produced in the school garden this year.

The boys' water closet is the filthiest and most foul smelling that I have ever inspected. It is a positive menace to the health of those using the building. The fecal matter is even on the floor and is being tracked into the school. The vault is too high and no urinal has been provided.

Sir,

I have the honor to refer to Department letter NO. 31-3-6A, dated December 8th, regarding neglect of duty on my part in connection with the Scotch Settlement School.

These repairs were done by Mr. Dan McVittie, Southampton, and were paid by voucher NO. 92 amounting to $22.45, dated December 8th, 1937.

I have personally placed a urinal in this closet twice, both times it has been taken away. Apparently the young people make use of these closets during the evening and nights and leave more dirt than the school children, to avoid this in the future I have purchased pad locks for use on both doors.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection of the Saugeen Agency on November 30th and December 2nd.

SCOTCH SETTLEMENT SCHOOL

This is a stone building. The outside woodwork is very badly in need of paint. Two of the porch standards are rotting away and should be replaced. The classroom is dingy; the walls and metal ceiling should be painted and two spots where the plaster is broken, repaired. Nothing has been done to the building for years. This has been done. The agent and teacher are both at fault for allowing such conditions to exist. The closet screens should be straightened and both closets and screens given a coat of red paint.

Extract from Inspector Game's report on the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School visited on May 3, 1944.

Accommodations should be improved in the following respects:

(1) Redecorate the classroom walls and ceiling which have become very darkened.

(2) Connect the cold air duct in the basement.

(3) Completely rebuild the screens around both toilets.

(4) Place a tile around the school foundation to keep water from seeping into the basement.

(5) Plow and fertilize the garden.
Ottawa,
May 12, 1944.

Mr. D. Robertson, Indian Agent, Chippawa Hill, Ont.

In reporting on his recent inspection of the Scotch Settlement School Inspector Game recommends:

1. Connect the cold air duct in the basement.
2. Completely rebuild the screens around both toilets.
3. Place a tile around the school foundation to keep water from seeping into the basement.
4. Plow and fertilize the garden.

If the garden has not been plowed you should arrange for this at once. It should not be necessary for the Inspector to comment on a matter such as this, as it is expected that all Indian agents will encourage the planning of school gardens and, of course, this involves plowing the ground.

Items 1, 2 and 3 should also receive early attention. The Department would appreciate your advising when you have carried out these instructions.

You might also obtain an estimate of the cost of redecorating the interior of the classroom.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to refer to Department letter No. 31-3-5, dated May 12th, regarding the Scotch Settlement School.

Regarding Nos. 1 and 2. I arranged with the local plumber and carpenter last spring to have this work done but as there is only the one local plumber and carpenter it is hard to get them to do work on the reserve, especially small jobs, however this will be completed as soon as possible.

Regarding No. 3. No doubt the Inspector is unaware that there is already a tile around the foundation of this school and also a six inch drain from the basement.

Regarding No. 4. There were very few local gardens plowed on May 3rd, date of his visit, the garden has been plowed, planted and is up and weeded. I do not see why the Inspector should comment on the garden not being plowed on May 3rd.

The redecorating of the class room would cost about $100.00. This class room was redecorated in 1939.

Don. Robertson,
Indian Agent.

Re: Scotch Settlement Indian Day School.

In the previous report of Inspector Game, April 19, 1948, he speaks fairly highly of the work being done by the teacher. With regard to the condition of the building he has made the following comments:

Improvements noted: (1) New screens by the toilet doors.

Recommendations:
(1) Wash class room walls. The pupils and teacher will clean the windows.
(2) A new furnace or at least extensive repairs to the present one which has no cold air ducts, a broken door, and a cracked pot which permits smoke to come into the classroom.
(3) Attach door on one toilet. These toilets both continue to be downright and unnecessarily filthy - a disgraceful condition to say the least.
(4) Glass for basement windows. The furnace room is very dark as the windows are boarded up.

It is suggested that glass be put in the basement windows and that they then be screened with heavy wiring. This is now obtainable and you are now authorized to have this work done during the summer holidays. This wire will have to be well fastened down and should be covered at the edges with boards.
It is presumed that we will hear from you with regard to the other repairs necessary at the school.

I would ask that you speak to Mr. Wells with regard to the conditions of the toilets, and tell him that we will require daily inspection of these toilets. If necessary he should select toilet monitors and make them responsible for cleaning these toilets each night. If these monitors are retained for work it will soon be found that all children will acquire an interest in the maintenance of cleanliness in these buildings.

If they are being used by adult Indians, you are authorized to purchase heavy locks for them now.

Bernard F. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.

Sir,

I have the honor to herewith enclose the account of John Heddle for the repairs of the Teachers dwelling at the Scotch settlement which amounts to $149.25 the contract price being $18.00 and the extras $31.25 these extras were not in the estimate of repairs but I think should have been. The cellar had no window on it. The stove pipe went through a hole in a partition without a chimney which made it very dangerous for fire. The kitchen needed the repairs inside to make it fit to live in on the winter time. The material used for that purpose is of the cheapest kind and the work only cost $5.00. The painting of it inside might have been done without but it would not be comfortable living in a room ceiled with lumber without it being painted. This is my reason for recommending the payment of this bill.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge official letter of April the 25th last No. 15397, referring to repairs of teachers' dwellings of this Reserve. As requested I herewith enclose estimate cost of repairs of Teachers' dwelling and fence at the Scotch Settlement.

In explanation I would inform the Dept. that there never was a soft water system in connection with the dwelling and I think it necessary to the comfort & convenience of the family.

The fence has been erected for 16 ft. 18 feet & consisted of a 10" board at the bottom, strands of smooth wire and a pole on top, the posts are 10' apart. The posts are too far apart for smooth wire and the wire too far apart on the posts, any animal as small as a sheep can go through the fence. Mr. Burr has kept the pigs out by making on boards at his own expense.

About one half of the post & top poles useless & requires new gates.

There is a quantity of stone lying at the fence and in heaps on the grounds. I propose building them into the fence between the posts 3' at the bottom 2' high and 2' at the top, using the smooth wire that is on the present fence on top of the stone, putting it close so that the animals cannot go through it.

This will

The roof of the dwelling required some repairing; I think by spending eight or ten dollars it will last a few years longer. The most of the corn-drying is very badly decayed.

Every room in the house requires papering and I think it should be done. Mr. Burr informs me it has never been done at the expense of the Dept.

Dear Sir,

I am obliged to trouble you again. You are no doubt aware that Deech Settlement School is 4 miles from P.O. 6 or 6½ miles from Southampton. At least 2 miles from a dwelling inhabited by whites. I am living here alone and have no means of getting out even excepting "looting it." I purposed bringing up a pony after Easter but when I visited the Stable on the premises found it positively unfit for either horse or pig. The Indians assured me they would make that all right after their Council but Mr. Sheffield informs me they turned the matter down by a vote of 25 to 25. I do not know whether he had the casting vote or not, but certain it is whoever had it failed to use it. I cannot tell whether it is their duty to provide a stable or not but as it stands I know no other course to pursue than to appeal to the Department. There is lumber enough about this big tumble-down affair to build a nice tidy little stable & drive house provided it is not too much warped to be of any use.

Hoping you will give this matter prompt attention.

I am Yours Respectfully,

Sir,

I have the honor to state re closet at the teacher's residence South Settlement Saugeen Reserve, that I found it in good repair except the roof which may leak some in an extra heavy rain.

The teacher told me that she did not ask the Dept. to have the W. Closet repaired that what she wanted was a new Closet built in the wood-shed in connection with the dwelling house, or the old Closet moved close to the Shed so that a door cut in the wall of the Shed would open into the Closet.

I told her that after my experience with a W. Closet in connection with the dwelling house, I could not recommend what she wanted. She then said that I need not do anything to the old Closet, that she would write again to the Dept. in regard to it.

I may say that my experience is that where there is no water works to keep a closet in connection with a dwelling house absolutely clean it becomes very unsanitary, to say the least is unpleasant.

The present Closet is 30 or 40 ft from the dwelling and if proper care is taken dry earth used in the Closet cleaned out 3 or 4 times a year, the condition is quite sanitary.

Will the Dept. kindly inform me, if I should move the Closet to where the teacher wants it or erect a new one where she wants it? Or what I should do in the matter.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,
John Geoffrill

I have the honor to state in reference to the water closet at the Teachers' dwelling Scotch settlement, Sauganash Reserve, that I have not been able to secure any person to do the work yet on account of the very cold and stormy weather.

The matter of removing the old closet was considered by the Indian Council at their last meeting when the following resolution was passed:

Moved by Mr. Macdonald, seconded by Mr. Maclean:
That the old closet at the Teachers' dwelling Scotch settlement be not removed, but a new closet be built in the corner of the woodshed for use in winter. That the building cost not more than ten or eleven dollars.

Certified correct.

I would recommend the above resolution to the favorable consideration of the Dept., for the reason that it would cost about as much to remove the old closet as to build the new one and the place can be kept in a more sanitary condition in summer.

I am obliged to make a protest against the treatment which I have been and am receiving at the hands of the agent.

The last time Mr. McQuillan was at my school I took both over to the house & pointed out the condition the house was in caused by smoking chimneys & defective chimney. I have spoken to the agent about them every time he has been here since the close of the war as his excuse at that time was "no one to do the work." It is four years at least since Mr. McQuillan ordered him, in presence of my daughters, to have the matter attended to but has not been touched. To-day the water is pouring in over every thing in the shed! The clock even cannot be used; this summer I had a bag of chips that cost $1 moulded & destroyed. I have been afraid to leave home for fear of rain pouring into parlor (as it always does when the wind is West or North or Southwesterly). I have a piano for which I paid over $500 & certainly it has had a good many moves to find a place where it would not be splashed by dust. The paper on the house is proof enough that what I say is true & it takes almost all summer to get the smell & smoke out of the clothing we in the house. The kitchen door & windows are so open that snow blows across the room during winter storms. The house outside requires re-painting as it is ruined almost past saving. Several who have seen the chimney have said that it is a menace to both life & property. Pieces of blackened brick come rattling down & soon the whole fabric may tumble.
The table too requires repairs. It has become so open & cold, the roadway up to the house & the culvert at the gate. The gates need by. The children are locked up because they will not close & have been for 4 years. We have to be kept in & Indian cattle kept out as I have pasture & garden to guard.

We also need a new fence around school yard & a flag pole. When the Agricultural representative (Mr. Harlowe & think his name is) was here I took him over with Mr. Stout & showed a piece of zinc piping my summer visitors nailed up on the parlor window so that the drip would all come down in one place. It is still there.

If it is not the agent's business to look after these things kindly advise me to whom I must appeal. Certainly things are in a dangerous as well as disagreeable condition. I never pays to leave anything until it is past repair especially in these H.C.L. days.

Yours Respectfully,

R. Robb.
Teacher.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, relative to the furnishings and repairs required in connection with the teacher's residence at the Scotch Settlement Indian Day School.

It is noted that there will be no furnishings on hand after Mrs. Robb leaves and that you estimate the cost of the furnishings required to be between $450 and $500. It is considered that this amount is excessive. The Department will approve of your arranging for the purchase and supplying of furniture, including bed and bedding, to an amount not exceeding $200. You may also expend the sum of $40 in the purchase of kitchen utensils; $40 in the purchase of curtains and rugs and $60 in the purchase of two stoves.

You should, if possible, obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers for the supplying of the above equipment, and you should place the order with the firm quoting the lowest price. While serviceable articles should be obtained, it is not intended that any expensive furnishings should be supplied. It would be advisable for you to consult the teacher and prepare a list of the articles needed, and you should then obtain prices. The above authorized amounts must not be exceeded, as it is considered that the furnishings required can be obtained for the amounts mentioned.

After the purchase has been made, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. You should attach to the accounts the quotations which you received from the merchants whom you asked to quote.

Relative to the repairs required to the roof and the redecorating of the residence, I have to request you to state whether it is absolutely necessary that the roof be repaired at the present time. If so, you should state the nature of the work required and the approximate cost thereof. You should also give an estimate of the cost of the redecorating required to the interior of the residence, stating the work you would recommend be carried out. Please give this matter your prompt attention and inform the Department at an early date as to what is required. You might state whether you could arrange for the purchase of the material required and for the labour, if it is necessary to reshingle the roof and carry out any redecorating in the interior of the residence.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I have the honor to reply to your letter No. 31-3-8, dated June 4th, with reference to the teacher's residence at the Scotch Settlement school.

I beg to say, this dwelling requires a new roof and the kitchen which is built onto the house needs new sills as the present ones are decaying and the kitchen is falling away from the main building. It will require 14 square of shingles to cover the house and kitchen. No. I, XXX British Columbia shingles cost $7.00 per Sq. and it would be $25.00 to place new sills under the kitchen. I could have this work all done by day labour cheaper than by contract as I could have Indians do the shingling. There are three rooms and a hall downstairs which should be repapered and the woodwork painted which would cost around $60.00. As the present teacher does not use the upstairs I do not think that part of the house need be redecorated at the present time. I will forward an estimate of the whitewashing of the school at an early date.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Please keep all expense as low as possible, having in view the supplying of a good grade of material and the satisfactory completion of the work.

March 23rd, 1876.

Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith for a communication under date 16th March, received from the Reverend Father of Garden River, Algoma:

"Dear Sir,

"I am writing to you about Indians. Last year, a great many Indians belonging to different reserves came to work at the new mill, and they camped there with their families. They are going to do the same next year, so I send another missionary. But also for the many children who will be there in six months, it would be much desirable to have a school. The teacher at Moosominaging (Reverend River House) might be removed there for the time being, and for a place to teach in, I found a fairly good house that we might buy or rent. I would be obliged to you if you would let me know as soon as possible what the Department is ready to do to help me by contributing and thus I may obtain more than half of the probable expenses, to add a little to the purchased house and to make desks and seats. I suspect I have to see 25 children there — and most likely, for a few years it will be the same. That is why I would rather buy than rent the house."

Respecting the matter, the Department

I beg respectfully to state that I would hardly feel justified in concurred with the reverend gentleman in his proposal to establish a school at Garden River, for the reason that any Indians who would go to the new mill for employment,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
