Dear Sir,

I am advised by your Department to place a certificated teacher at the Serpent River Indian School. The chief and the Indians here have placed in the school a half-breed woman that has no certificate to teach. They claim that they have been authorized by your Department to do so and will not part with her because she knows the Indian language, as they themselves do. Her name is Josephine Biaillon. She is here with her husband and children, among whom a baby. She created a great disturbance here, having persuaded the chief and the other Indians, that your Department does not require certificate teachers for Indian schools, that such is but a notion of my own. Please let Indians know if they are to continue Josephine Biaillon in their school or not, and oblige.

Yours very truly,

C. R. Richard,
Indian Missionary.
To the Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.

We have made a great mistake by appointing our teacher, but we are not altogether to blame, for we were sure that what Mr. Ross told us was sufficient. We would have made more inquiries but both Father Richard and Father Pauquin told us that they had nothing to do with the school. The chief asked Father Pauquin but he told me he had nothing to do with the school in the presence of a lot of others. Mr. Ross advised us to have a meeting among ourselves and all of us to sign our names and to send it to him and he would arrange the matter with the Department, and it is what we done and we asked Mrs. Beaulieu to be our teacher and she agreed. She was leaving here the very day she made our agreement with Mr. Ross we also told him whom we had for our teacher and he recommended her as being a good teacher and he seemed to be pleased about it.

On the 16th of November we advised Mrs. Beaulieu to begin teaching which she did. On the 27th of November Father Richard arrived here and found Josephine Beaulieu teaching he was real angry about it and he put teacher and children all out of the school. He told us the wish of the Department was to have a certificated teacher but we did not know what it meant. We then received a letter from Mr. Ross which stated that the Department would give us a teacher and that Mrs. Beaulieu was teaching without authority. Mrs. Beaulieu has no certificate and she explained to us what it was. We find her to be good and agreeable and can also speak in our language and help us a lot.
Father Richard advised her to keep on teaching till further instructions from the Department. We would very much like her to stay there is not one of us that is not wanting her, so we beg your assistance to let her stay although she has no certificate. Please let us know as soon as possible what we must do and please let us please give her a trial, let us have our wish for once. She has been recommended to us by a good many.

We Remain

Dear Sir,

We are in trouble for our school.

Mrs. Ross, the Indian Agent was here sometime in October, and we asked him to change our teacher Mrs. Mary Ada, and we asked that Mrs. Josephine Beallows take her place. His answer was that he was willing that she may teach, that he had known her as being a good teacher, and he advised us to have a meeting among ourselves and sign our names to our agreement and send it to him (Mrs. Ross) and that he (Mrs. Ross) would forward it to the Department. We took it for granted that Mrs. Beallows was to be our teacher.

She was in this place when Mrs. Ross was here. She was leaving this place for her home with her husband in a sail boat the day Mrs. Ross was here. We inquired to Mrs. Ross at once if she could be our teacher, and as he said he was willing we turned back to tell Mrs. Beallows that she was to be our teacher. They had already left the landing place and were about 20 yards from the shore when we made them turn back, and told them to be sure and come back and to bring their furniture that we would furnish them a house. They were away three weeks when they arrived again the 8th November; in a week's time they were settled and we advised her to begin to teach school Monday 16th November. Before we had seen Mrs. Ross we spoke to Father Pauquin about changing our teacher; he told us to ask Father Richard. When Father Richard arrived she was anxious about having another teacher; he said he had nothing to do with the school and that he did not want to have anything to do with it.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of the 26th received. It will be eighteen years next May since I commenced to teach Indian schools and I feel that I would like a rest. So thought of resigning just before next navigation closed, or at Christmas all being well, or I would like to take up these studies the Department wishes teachers of Indian schools to take up.

On April 1st this school William Gipuz died Feb 10th. He had two hemorrhages died during the second one. MEMORANDUM

Mr. McLean,

Mrs. Jessie H. Mackay, who has been in the employ of the Department for the past twenty years as an Indian school teacher, has resigned her position as teacher of the Serpent River Indian School. It is most likely that this school will be closed, as any of the Indians who remain at Serpent River can send their children to the Spanish River Industrial School. The mill at Serpent River, which afforded employment for the Indians, has closed down and most of them have to seek employment elsewhere.

Secretary,

Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I regret to inform you that during my absence yesterday the Indian School at Kenabutch was burned. The cause of the fire is unknown to me as it first broke out in the front wall, but I can only believe that the rats must have carried matches and started it, as the stoves and pipes were 16 ft. removed from where the blaze was first discovered and there had been no fresh fires made for 2 hours previous.

I had just left there a few minutes before to come to Cutler and while here was informed that it was burning. I received such a shock that it was a few minutes before I could hurry to the scene.

When I arrived, the Indians had broken the door and were at work moving furniture, my personal belongings, etc., They had found it impossible to quench the fire as it was running along the dry pine boards.

In a very few minutes a large number of people were there and succeeded in saving everything except the bare building. They even removed window frames without breaking the glass, took off doors and moved both stoves and stove pipes.
I phoned Mr. Agent Hagan and found him quarantined on account of Influenza, so he asked me to give you a detailed description of the fire.

We stored the bed, my desk, and books in the church but there was no room for other furniture there, so it is outside without any covering so far.

I am going out today to see if I can find some place to store it till you advise what will be done about re-building school or building a small shed to store the furniture in; as I am sure that if we do secure a place it will be only temporary.

Acting on Mr. Hagan's advice I closed school Oct. 22nd as quite a number of my pupils were suffering from Influenza and there are quite a few cases at present, but not as many deaths as in the neighboring Indian towns. Dr. Robb thinks it will be almost a month before we could resume class work. I am sorry to say that all the deaths were a result of scorning Dr. Robb's advice as to medicine, nursing, etc.

On account of an impending nervous break-down I had decided, before the fire, to ask you to accept my resignation at the completion of this quarter and had a letter written to this effect yesterday and was on my way to the Post Office with it when I heard that the school was burning. So I decided to wait and report on the fire and tender my resignation at the same time.

I have sent in a requisition for necessary school material through Mr. Hagan Agent to the Department, but have not received the supplies, and am greatly in need of same.

As you know, Mr. Sutherland does staying at the boarding house in Peter, and as it is a company boarding house and well filled with its own employees, and there is quite a bit of inconvenience caused by my being there. But, in this place, there is no private boarding house where I could stay, or would stay, and as for doing as Miss Gallagher did it is impossible as there is no room in the present building.

I am paying $1.00 per day for board, and from now on it will be increased to nine dollars per week. You know, Mr. Sutherland, on my present salary it is impossible...
to pay such a board bill. I would rather an increase in salary to twenty dollars or that much paid on my board bill.

Another thing is, I had to buy a pair of rubber boots in order to come through the woods as they are now. They were $3.45 in the store here and I do not think I should have to pay for them myself. And also, my room at the boarding house is hardly cold, but I cannot make any complaint to the company, as those rooms are just for their employees and most of them have stories. I need a little coal oil stove to heat mine, and I think the Department should furnish same, and the oil that would be used in it.

I think this is very little considering all things Miss Gallagher had all the furniture and housekeeping affairs arranged and by living as she did, will do so much cheaper than I can do now. I have signed my classification card regarding the bonus, but have heard nothing more about it.

Mr. Lutheland, I trust the Department will give this letter its consideration and arrange those matters satisfactorily as soon as possible.

Dear Sir:

The following is an extract from Inspector Greening's report regarding his visit to the Serpent River Indian Day School on the 7th ultimo:

"While I was in the district, certain representations were made to me in regard to this school.

It would appear, (and I am quoting entirely from hearsay), that Miss Bush has formed some connection with a resident of Blind River, and has a habit of proceeding to Blind River, on week-ends, to visit him. He, for his part, reciprocates occasionally by coming up to Cutler to visit the teacher.

The relations are most likely purely platonic, but some of the Indians place a less charitable construction upon the matter, complaining that the example presented to their children is not of the best, and, as a result, petitioned the Department for a change of teachers - the Department can readily check the accuracy of this latter statement. Moreover, the affair forms a succulent morsel for conversation along the line.

I am not, personally, very prone towards taking such notice of neighbourhood scandal, but, in this case, there are two points bearing upon the efficiency of the Indian school system: (1) If the situation is as stated, is the teacher showing just the example desired in Indian schools? and (2) What effect is being made upon public opinion in regard to such schools?

C. Rothera, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.
Were it not for these two points, (and this is not the first time that they have been called to my attention), I should not be inclined to interfere with any individual's personal affairs. As it is, I am merely reporting that such representations have been made in order that the Department may make such enquiries, (if any), upon its own account as may be deemed worth while.

I should merely like to say that, in my opinion, Miss Bush, in a situation where the counter-attractions are not too strong, is capable of doing really efficient work with Indian children, and it might be a good plan to exchange her with a teacher more remote from Blind River.

Please report fully regarding the Inspector's remarks and state whether or not you are aware if there is any truth in the remarks that the Inspector has heard.

Would you consider it advisable to transfer Miss Bush to the Sagamock School and send Miss Kelly to Serpent River after the holidays, or do you believe it would be in the best interests of the work to dispense with the services of Miss Bush?

The Department would appreciate an early reply in which you should state your views as fully as possible.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

To Hon. T.A. Crerar,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

We, the undersigned petitioners, beg to submit the following matter for your consideration.

Your petitioners humbly pray that a qualified teacher be appointed to our Indian day school here at the Serpent River Indian reserve.

Our present teacher Miss Ada Bush has been here for more than five years, and has not passed any pupil for the entrance to High School during the time she has been teaching. And as a result, the pupils who were anxious to pass the entrance examinations are discouraged; and with a further result are now indifferent about attending school.

It is our belief, that the Government's aim is to encourage Indians to get proper education; and with this belief, we feel confident that you will not fail to meet our petition for a capable and qualified teacher.

In duty bound, your petitioners will ever pray for the fulfilment of our humble request.

Approved and adopted at the Band Council, held for that purpose at Serpent River reserve; Cutler, Ont. this 28th day of May 1937.

Dear Sir,

When I sent in my application in January for this teaching position, I stated that I was willing to sacrifice my fifth form subjects but not my fourth form subjects. They are "Latin and Physics" which I have been taking by myself and with the help of our High School principal in Blind River up till now. I find it impossible to be able to keep it up especially now and in the month of June. I have examination papers to prepare and correct for eight grades. I have plenty of work to do since the pupils are so far behind. This is my third year repeating in "Latin" and my second year repeating in "Physics". Is it possible to secure educational credits in those two subjects? I would be very grateful because it is my intention of attending Normal School next year. A speedy reply would enable me to decide upon my future.

Thanking you,

I remain,

Yours truly,

Paul Berthelot

Dear Mr. Chelan,

I have your letter of the twenty-eighth instant, with reference to not being able to grant educational credits.

The Department of Agriculture, Ontario Farm Service Force, Toronto, secure credits to students willing to work on farms. You may say: "That is vital above work." Well, so is teaching; since so many teachers are wanted today. The demand for them is very great.

I deduct from all this, that you could at least try to intercede by the Department of Education for me. If you insist to the department that you really need me and that almost complete my year and June is the hardest month, I think my point is clear and reasonable and would consider it as a favour. Please make a quick move answering because I cannot afford to lose any more time. It is of no use studying now since I have too many things in my head at present.
I am but nineteen years of age and wished to get somewhere.

If the Department of Education refuses to grant me credits, I will be obliged to quit my job at the earliest date possible. After all, my future comes before anything else.

You could very well explain to the Dept. that it is my intention of going to Normal School next year. The Dept. could write to my principal for my standing in school.

Hoping that you will take quick action in this matter,

Thanking you,

I remain,

Yours truly,
Paul Berthelot.

Madam,

In your case you taught 20 days in the September quarter, and you were paid $70.00 of your yearly salary of $700, or $70.00. For the December and March quarters teachers are usually paid one-quarter of their yearly salary for each quarter. This was done in your case, and payment of $175.00 was made for each quarter.

If you continue in charge of this school until the end of the current quarter, viz: June 30th, next, the amount necessary to make up your full yearly salary will be paid. In your case, the amount due you, and which will be paid on the receipt of your June quarter return, is $280.

Sir,

Ottawa, November 23rd, 1926.

Sir;

I have your letter of the 19th instant, relative to the services being performed by Miss Irene Spottswood, teacher of the Serpent River Indian Day School. In view of the report of the Separate School Inspector and yourself that her work is unsatisfactory, I have to request that you will inform her that her services will not be required after the end of December, next.

The Department has noted your recommendation that Miss Helen Connolly, teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School, be transferred to Serpent River. We are not prepared to authorize this transfer. We will endeavour to secure the services of a suitable teacher to succeed Miss Spottswood, to begin duties when the school reopens after the coming Christmas holidays, on or about January 2nd, next. If, however, you have a qualified teacher in view, you might submit the name, qualifications and experience for the consideration of the Department.

Please notify Miss Spottswood as soon as possible of the termination of her services from the above mentioned date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Aat. Deputy and Secretary.

Sheraton June 28th 1923

At a council held in the church at Butler by the different River Band of Indians present 13 of the head men of the Band together with the chief and myself the following resolutions were passed.

It was moved by Louis Meahmogaid seconded by William Stevenson that if the Indian Department at Ottawa will grant us money out of our funds to purchase the materials for a school house we will do all the work and complete the building; and we will also clear and plow and properly cultivate one acre of ground and fence the same for school premises for the sum of thirty dollars.

The Indians will build the house themselves without pay but they wish to have 30 dollars for clearing and plowing and harrowing and building a fence around the school grounds which they propose shall be one acre of land.

My own opinion is that the offer is reasonable.

Sir,

I beg leave to again bring to your notice the advisability of building a schoolhouse at Butler on the Serpent River reserve.

They have been using the church for I don't know how long, but now they have shut the church door and will not allow the school to be held in it. I sent the former teacher, Mr. Smith, down there and there was no place to hold school, and the priest-in-charge will not open the church; rather than let the teacher go, I rented a house for one month until I could hear from you about the schoolhouse which they said to build. The whole band are unanimous in wishing to build a schoolhouse and it was unanimously decided and unanimously they would do the work of building if the chief would buy the material out of his funds. Lumber is very high and it would cost about two hundred dollars or perhaps a little more. Please let me know if done right in renting a house for school purposes I agreed to pay four dollars per month. It is hard to get teachers who are qualified to pay so low.

Sheraton Sept 25th 1900

Sir,

In answer to your letter No. 875 of last month I beg leave to say that the Indians have said repeatedly that they did not want the present new school as the most of the people who have children are living at Butler and those who are still living at Sheraton River who have children are going to move to Butler. I beg to say that after I rented a house for a school house the Priest in charge of the church at Butler gave us permission to use it for a time so we have no rent to pay as we are holding school in the church the same as usual, but I hope the Department will see their way clear to build a school house or at least to provide the material and allow the Indians to build it.

I am in your obedient servant,

Samuel Hayan
Indian agent

Extract from a Report of the Committee Honourable the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency on the 16th October, 1900.

On a Memorandum dated 3rd October, 1900, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, stating that the Agent for the Serpent River Band of Indians, in the Thessalon Agency, Ontario, has reported in favour of a school house being erected at Cutter for the use of the band, at a cost of $300.; and the Indians have passed a resolution requesting that they be authorized to make the expenditure from their capital funds.

The Minister recommends, as the school house when completed would be in the nature of a permanent improvement, that under Section 139, of the Indian Act, authority be given for the erection of the same and for charging the cost thereof, as above stated, to the capital at the credit of the said band, which amounts to $5,827.71.

The Committee submit the same for Your Excellency's approval.

Dear Sir,

I come now from Butten in the Agency of Thessalon, where upon recommendation of Mr. Inspector White, I accompanied Miss Julia Moran to take care of the school. I notified Miss Moran herself that she kept this school part month and May, but not come back since. I had to send some body else to take her place.

While I was at Butten, the Indians told me that orders had come from Ottawa to build a school house and another house for the teacher. May I respectfully suggest that it would be less expensive and quite as comfortable to the teacher, if one same building contained a room large enough for class purposes, and two smaller ones for the teacher, with a shed for wood.

The chief is not now at Butten. Besides, I do not think that he or any other Indians of that reserve could properly do work. It would be better that Mr. Agent Sam Hogan give the contract to some reliable men among the white people of Butten or Thessalon.

Remain dear Sir,

Your servant in the Lord

J. Q. Orton

Superior of R. C. Missions
OTTAWA, 29th May, 1901.

Sir,

In connection with previous correspondence in regard to the proposed erection of a new schoolhouse for the Serpent River Indians at Cutler, I have to request that you will be good enough to advise the Department what steps have been taken in this direction.

You are aware that the sum of $300.00 is all that is available for the purchase of materials for this building and the Rev. Father Artus now writes the Department that provision should be made for two small rooms for the teacher's use in addition to the class-room.

Please inform the Department whether the Indians are prepared to carry out the work if the material is supplied.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLEAN

Sir,

The Indians of Butten, Serpent River Band, have got out the bills for their school house, and wish to have the material purchased for them; they propose building according to one of the plans sent to me last fall, size 32 x 22. That will be large enough for a teacher's room on one end.
